{{Multiple issues| {{tone|date=November 2008}} {{refimprove|date=October 2008}} {{Update|date=October 2014}} }}
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Great Recession sidebar}} The European recession is part of the [[Great Recession]], which began inside the United States. The crisis spread to '''Europe''' rapidly and affected much of the region with several countries already in [[recession]] as of February 2009, and most others suffering marked economic setbacks. The global recession was first seen in Europe, as [[Ireland]] was the first country to fall in a recession from Q2-Q3 2007 – followed by temporary growth in Q4 2007 – and then a two-year-long recession.<ref name="CSO Quarterly National Accounts: Q4-2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.cso.ie/en/media/csoie/releasespublications/documents/latestheadlinefigures/qna_q42012.pdf |title=Quarterly National Accounts -Quarter 4 2012|format=PDF|publisher=CSO |date=21 March 2013 |accessdate=20 September 2013}}</ref>
==Timeline of the Great Recession across all continents== {{Timeline of the Great Recession}}
==Eurozone== The Eurozone recession has been dated from the first quarter of 2008 to the second quarter of 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cepr.org/data/dating/ |title=Euro Area Business Cycle Dating Committee |publisher=Cepr.org }}</ref> In the eurozone as a whole, industrial production fell 1.9 percent in May 2008, the sharpest one-month decline for the region since the exchange rate crisis in 1992. European car sales fell 7.8 percent in May compared with a year earlier.<ref name=Europeanrecession>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2008/07/15/ccspain115.xml |title=European recession looms as Spain crumbles|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=18 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-19 | location=London | first=Ambrose | last=Evans-Pritchard}}</ref> Retail sales fell by 0.6 percent in June from the May level and by 3.1 percent from June in the previous year. Germany was the only country out of the four biggest economies in the eurozone to register an increase of activity in July though the increase was sharply down. Economic analysts from RBS and capital Economics say the decline raises the risk of the eurozone entering a recession in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gtD5TceLXMkNchzj_VpBHYfzsVYA|title=Eurozone business activity 'close to seven-year low'|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=6 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref> In the second quarter, the eurozone's economy was reported to have declined by 0.2 percent.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/markets/2008/08/14/europe-briefing-update-markets-equity-cx_je_0814markets24.html |title=Europe: Oil Falls, Stocks Rise |work=[[Forbes]] |date=14 August 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018234737/http://www.forbes.com/markets/2008/08/14/europe-briefing-update-markets-equity-cx_je_0814markets24.html |archivedate=18 October 2008 }}</ref>
===Ireland=== {{Further|Post-2008 Irish economic downturn}} The global recession was first seen in Europe, as [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] was the first country to fall in a recession from Q2-Q3 2007 – followed by temporary growth in Q4 2007 – and then a two-year-long recession.<ref name="CSO Quarterly National Accounts: Q4-2012"/> Republic of Ireland in the first quarter of 2008 reported a contraction in GDP of 1.5 percent, its first economic contraction since it began reporting by quarter and first recorded contraction since 1983.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2008/06/30/ap5168638.html|title=Ireland's economy shrinks 1.5 percent|agency=Associated Press |work=[[Forbes]]|date=30 June 2008|accessdate=2008-07-19 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080710124111/http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2008/06/30/ap5168638.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 10 July 2008}}</ref> However, Ireland's Central Statistics Office reported growth in GNP of about 0.8 percent, Ireland's government considers GNP a better measure of the economy. Analysts have predicted Ireland's economy will contract further in the rest of the year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5hN05zexiwjoE0at_dj8IEdxD0-BQ|title=Ireland faces recession after Celtic Tiger era|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=30 June 2008|accessdate=2008-07-19}}</ref> A report from NCB Stockbrokers predicts gross national product will fall by 1 percent in 2008 and by 0.4 percent in 2009 due to a decline in multinationals hit by the global economic slowdown.{{When|date=December 2009}} An economist from NCB said non-residential investment would fall by 5 percent in 2008 and by 12 percent in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2008/0731/economy-business.html|title=Latest economic report predicts recession|publisher=RTÉ Business|date=29 July 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
Ireland's GDP saw a contraction in the second quarter by 0.5 percent, making Ireland the first member of the eurozone to enter a recession.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7635426.stm|title=Irish economy goes into recession|publisher=BBC News|date=25 September 2008|accessdate=2008-09-26}}</ref> The government is being advised by Merrill Lynch, the American broker that ran out of capital in September 2008.<ref>Irish Independent, 28 January 2009, p.21</ref> In January 2009 it was [[Anglo Irish Bank hidden loans controversy|forced to nationalise]] its third largest bank, [[Anglo Irish Bank]] and to announce recapitalisation of its top two banks, [[Allied Irish Bank|AIB]] and [[Bank of Ireland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0121/angloirish.html|title=McAleese signs Anglo Irish Bank Bill|date=21 January 2009|accessdate=2009-01-21|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]}}</ref> In February 2009, the government announced record unemployment levels in the country, with its highest monthly increase in 40 years and 1,500 people being laid off daily.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0204/employment.html|title=Jobless rate could hit 400,000 – Cowen|date=4 February 2009|accessdate=2009-02-04|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]]}}</ref> Ireland exited the recession in the 3rd quarter of 2009, posting a 0.3% growth in its economy, due to recent heavy budget cuts by the Irish government. However, although they technically exited recession, the Irish economy still has a lot of hurdles to overcome if it is to return to normality.
===Spain=== {{Further|2008–13 Spanish financial crisis}} Spain's [[Martinsa-Fadesa]], a construction company, declared bankruptcy after failing to refinance a debt of €5.1 billion. The two banks with most exposure to Martinsa-Fadesa were reportedly [[Caja Madrid]], at €900m, and [[Banco Popular Español]], at €400m. Spain's finance minister [[Pedro Solbes]] said it would not bail out the company. In the second quarter, house prices in Spain fell 20 percent.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2008/07/17/cnspain117.xml|title= Spain drops reassuring gloss as crisis deepens|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=18 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-19 | location=London | first=Ambrose | last=Evans-Pritchard}}</ref> In Castilla-La Mancha some 69 percent of all houses built over the past three years are still unsold. [[Deutsche Bank]] said it expects a 35 percent fall in real house prices by 2011. Spain's premier, Jose Luis Zapatero, blamed the European Central Bank for making matters worse by raising interest rates. More than 98 percent of home loans in Spain are priced off floating rates linked to [[Euribor]], which has risen 145 basis points since August. Housing accounts for over 10 percent of Spain's economy. The [[Bank of Spain]] is concerned about the health of smaller regional lenders with heavy exposure to the mortgage market.
Although Spain has avoided recession in the first half of 2008, unemployment in the country has risen by 425,000 over 2007-2008, reaching 9.9 percent. Car sales in Spain fell 31 percent in May.<ref name=Europeanrecession /> Spain's factory output slumped 5.5 percent in May 2008. The country's business lobby Circulo de Empresarios warned of a "high probability" that Spain's economy would fall into recession in the second half of 2008 due to the housing collapse.<ref name=Recessionwarnings>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2008/07/08/cnger108.xml |title=Recession warnings ruffle Europe as Germany and Italy stall|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=11 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-19 |location=London |first=Ambrose |last=Evans-Pritchard}}</ref> Spain had a 7.9 percent decline in retail sales in June compared to the previous year, the largest drop since Spain began registering the results and the seventh consecutive monthly decline. This included a 17.9 percent drop in retail sales of household goods. June food sales in Spain fell by 6.8 percent.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/rbssConsumerGoodsAndRetailNews/idUKL063246920080730 |title=Spanish retail sales suffer record fall |agency=Reuters |date=30 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
[[Morgan Stanley]] issued a major alert on the health of Spanish banks and the Spanish economy in a report, saying, "A momentous economic slowdown is now under way. We believe the deterioration in Spain is just in the beginning stages. The bulk of the pain will be suffered in 2009." Morgan Stanley also warned there was 40 percent chance of a 0.5 percent contraction of the Spanish economy in 2009, with a risk of an even more extreme 1.4 percent contraction in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2008/08/05/ccspain105.xml|title=Morgan Stanley issues alert on Spanish banks|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=4 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11 | location=London | first=Ambrose | last=Evans-Pritchard}}</ref> According to Spanish automobile manufacturers' association ANFAC new car sales fell 27.5 percent in July from the same time in 2007, the third consecutive monthly drop of over 20 percent. Spain's government forecast the unemployment rate would rise to 10.4 percent in 2008 and to 12.5 percent in 2009. Spain's second largest bank [[BBVA]] predicted the unemployment rate could reach 14 percent in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gTvMnsqLq1rIdhBfsYmeAFy7cpaw|title=Spain facing worse economic slowdown than expected|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|date=9 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref> Spain's Purchasing Managers Index for the manufacturing sector in July fell to a new low suggesting a deep recession.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/feedarticle/7694042|title=Euro zone factory activity at 5-yr low, prices rising|work=The Guardian|date=1 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11 | location=London}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> In the second quarter Spain's economy grew by 0.1 percent, the lowest gain in 15 years.<ref name=Forbes />
As of December 2009, Spain's government forecast the unemployment rate would rise to 20 percent in 2009. It's predicted a 25% rate, due to the way the tally is carried out by the government.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12987582 Mounting joblessness in Spain | And worse to come], The Economist, 22 January 2009</ref> According to Spain's Finance Minister, the "Spain faces its deepest recession in half a century".<ref>[http://www.barcelonareporter.com/index.php?/pg_print_article/solbes_says_spain_faces_deepest_recession_in_50_years/ Solbes Says Spain Faces Deepest Recession in 50 Years] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707213224/http://www.barcelonareporter.com/index.php?%2Fpg_print_article%2Fsolbes_says_spain_faces_deepest_recession_in_50_years%2F |date=7 July 2011 }}, Barcelona Reporter, 16 January 2009</ref>
===Germany=== In Germany officials had warned the economy could contract by as much as 1.5 percent in the second quarter because of declining export orders. The economy of Germany indeed contracted in both the second and third quarters putting Germany now in a technical recession.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/nov/14/oecd-recession-germany-inflation-deflation | title= Germany officially in recession as OECD expects US to lead recovery|work=The Guardian |date=14 November 2008 | location=London | first=Kathryn | last=Hopkins | accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref> Although the idea was fought for a moment Angela Merkel and the German government approved a €50 billion strong rescue plan to protect the German economy of the crisis, making of it Western Europe's biggest rescue plan for now in this crisis.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20090106-germany-agrees-new-50-billion-euro-stimulus-plan |title=Germany agrees on 50-billion-euro stimulus plan |publisher=France 24 |date=6 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110513022443/http://www.france24.com/en/20090106-germany-agrees-new-50-billion-euro-stimulus-plan |archivedate=13 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Germany's industrial output was down 2.4 percent in May, the fastest rate for a decade. Orders have now fallen for six months in a row, the worst run since the early 1990s.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601068&refer=home&sid=asVhpVLebe1Q |title= German Economy Enters Worst Recession in 12 Years | publisher= Bloomberg | date= 13 November 2008}}</ref> The German Chamber of Industry and Commerce warned of up to 200,000 job losses in coming months.<ref name=Recessionwarnings /> German retails sales fell 1.4 percent in June more than any expectations.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/feedarticle/7693887|title=German June retail sales fall adds to economic gloom |work= The Guardian|date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-11 |location=London }} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> The German economy declined by 0.5 percent in the second quarter.<ref name=Forbes />
===Greece=== {{see also|European sovereign-debt crisis}}
In 2012 Greece entered its 5th year of recession.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cityam.com/latest-news/greek-recession-near-entering-its-fifth-straight-year |title=Greek recession is near to entering its fifth straight year |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref> In 2011 Greece's GDP shrunk by a further 6.8%, leaving total economic output now 16% below the pre-crisis peak. [[Eurostat]]'s current forecasts also show Greece's economy declining further in 2012, by an estimated 4.4%<ref>{{cite news |title=Another Battering for Europe as Oil Costs hit Record High |work=The Times |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/business/industries/naturalresources/article3330148.ece |date=24 February 2012 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref>
===Italy=== In Italy, [[Fiat]] announced plant closures and temporary layoffs at factories in Turin, Melfi and Sicily. Car sales in Italy have fallen by almost 20 percent over each of the past two months. Italy's car workers' union said; "The situation is evidently more serious than had been understood."<ref name=Recessionwarnings /> On 10 July 2008 economic think tank ISAE lowered its growth forecast for Italy to 0.4 percent from 0.5 percent and cut the 2009 outlook to 0.7 percent from 1.2 percent.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/feedarticle/7666684|title=German finance ministry writes off Q2 GDP| work= The Guardian|date= 21 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-22 |location=London}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Analysts have predicted Italy had entered a recession in the second quarter or would enter one by the end of the year with business confidence at its lowest levels since the [[September 11 attacks]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/feedarticle/7674835|title=Italy business morale hits 7-year low, recession seen|work=The Guardian|date=24 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-25 | location=London}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Italy's economy contracted by 0.3 percent in the second quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601068&sid=a4eQgSi4DaSU&refer=home|title=Italy's Economy Unexpectedly Shrinks; Nears Recession|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=8 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
The unemployment rate rose from 5.7% in April 2007 to 8.6% in April 2010. Italy was mostly isolated from the effects of the Great Recession of 2008-2009 as their banking system did not engage in risky investment behavior and was sound. However, the effects of the recession wiped out the strict budget discipline that Italy had painstakingly kept since the Debt Crisis of 1992, and lead to another Italian sovereign debt crisis in 2011. Italy briefly saw growth from 2009-2011, but from 2011 to 2013 suffered a recession that, while shallower than the 2008-2009 downturn, was longer and in many ways far worse, as unemployment skyrocketed 7.9% in April 2011 to 13.0% in November 2014.
===France, Benelux countries=== Other eurozone members saw a decline in their economies in the second quarter as well; France by 0.3 percent, [[Finland]] by 0.2 percent while the [[Netherlands]] showed zero growth in the second quarter.<ref name="Forbes"/> However the final estimates released by the [[INSEE]], France's statistical agency, showed the French economy grew by 0.14 percent during the third quarter thus barely avoiding a technical recession.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://pdfinvest.com/france-avoids-recession-and-defies-economists.html|title=France Avoids Recession And Defies Economists|publisher=PDFinvest.com|date = 2 December 2008}}</ref> In the first quarter of 2009, France fell into recession, the last developed nation in Europe to do so.
In order to fight the economic crisis, French president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] announced a €26 billion rescue plan which will amount to an additional €15.5 billion in addition to the normal budget for 2009 and will increase France's public deficit to 4%. It is similar, to an extent, to Barack Obama's proposal to stimulate the U.S. economy by investing in the nation's vital infrastructure. Further proposals include tax rebates for small businesses as well as easing restrictions on building permits and government contracts particularly with construction and civil engineering. <ref>{{cite news |url=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/speciales/economie/20081204.OBS3901/plan_de_relance__le_detail_des_mesures_annoncees_par_sa.html |title=http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/la-crise-financiere/20081204.OBS3901/plan-de-relance-le-detail-des-mesures-annoncees-par-sarkozy.html |language=French |publisher=NouvelObs.com |date=5 December 2008 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref>
This is due to the "prime à la casse" program where buyers received a rebate of up to €1,000 for scrapping their polluting old vehicles and purchasing new environmentally friendly/ fuel efficient cars. As a consequence, car sales in France in December 2008 were 30% higher than in December 2007 although on the total 2008 year the sales was down 0.7%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises/industrie/automobile/20090106trib000328250/la-prime-a-la-casse-dope-les-commandes-dautomobiles-.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130213110528/http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises/industrie/automobile/20090106trib000328250/la-prime-a-la-casse-dope-les-commandes-dautomobiles-.html |archive-date=13 February 2013 |title=La prime à la casse dope les commandes d'automobiles |language=French |work=La Tribune |date=6 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2009-01-11 |df=dmy-all }} </ref> Because the French new cars market fared better than most as well as increased sales in South America, French brands, particularly Renault, now have bigger shares of the world's market despite selling fewer cars in 2008 than in 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises/industrie/automobile/20090109trib000329530/renault-ventes-mondiales-en-baisse-en-2008-mais-part-de-marche-en-hausse-.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20090122055141/http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises/industrie/automobile/20090109trib000329530/renault-ventes-mondiales-en-baisse-en-2008-mais-part-de-marche-en-hausse-.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 January 2009 |title=Renault : ventes mondiales en baisse en 2008 mais part de marché en hausse |language=French |work=La Tribune |date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-11 }}</ref> Another highly exposed industry is naval construction, an order concerning a packet boat for [[Norwegian Cruise Line|NCL]] was already cancelled.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.journaldunet.com/economie/actualite/depeche/reuters/317/600870/ncl_annule_la_commande_d_un_paquebot_a_stx_europe.shtml |title=NCL annule la commande d'un paquebot à STX Europe |language=French |publisher=Journaldunetv.com |date=18 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-13}}</ref>
In order to fill the blank in the construction planning the French government is expected to order soon a third [[Mistral class amphibious assault ship|Mistral BPC]], as well as smaller ships, for the French navy to [[DCNS (company)|DCNS]]. This is part of the Sarkozy's rescue plan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.meretmarine.com/article.cfm?id=109092 |title=L'Etat va commander un BPC, des engins de débarquement et des navires d'instruction |language=French |publisher=Meretmarine.com |date=18 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-11}}</ref> DCNS also won its biggest export contract ever when the Brazilian government placed a €7 billion large order to the company. The order concerns four [[Scorpène class submarine]] with a conventional propulsion and a fifth one with a nuclear propulsion, as well as a naval shipyard and a naval base.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.meretmarine.com/article.cfm?id=109144 |title=DCNS remporte le plus gros contrat à l'export de son histoire |language=French |publisher=Meretmarine.com |date=23 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-11}}</ref>
The French cooperative bank [[Groupe Caisse d'Epargne|Caisse d'Epargne]] suffered a €600 million [[derivative (finance)|derivatives]] trading loss in October 2008, which it blamed partly on the high market [[Volatility (finance)|volatility]] at the time.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7675574.stm|title=French bank admits trading loss|date=17 October 2008|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2008-10-17}}</ref> The group of employees responsible for making the unauthorised trades were dismissed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/10/17/business/caisse.php|title=French lender uncovers €600 million loss on unauthorized trading|last=Saltmarsh|first=Matthew|date=17 October 2008|work=[[International Herald Tribune]]|accessdate=2008-10-17}}</ref> French banks have also been affected to some point by the fraud set by [[Bernard Madoff]]. Most importantly [[Natixis]], an investment bank, potentially lost €450 million in the process and [[BNP Paribas]] could lose €350 million. Neither Natixis or BNP Paribas directly invested in Madoff's but through bonds issued by the US treasury they could face such loses. It is to be determined if all of these are effectively lost, which ones can be recovered and what can be saved by legal procedures. Other groups like [[AXA]], [[Société Générale]], [[Crédit Agricole]] and [[Groupama]] could also face loses to some point.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lesechos.fr/info/finance/300316963-affaire-madoff-natixis-bnp-paribas-societe-generale-casa-axa-devoilent-leur-exposition.htm |title=Affaire Madoff : Natixis, BNP Paribas, Société Générale, Casa, AXA... dévoilent leur exposition |language=French |work=Les Échos|location=France |date=15 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-11}}</ref>
On 28 September 2008, Dutch-[[Belgium|Belgian]] bank [[Fortis (finance)|Fortis]] was partially [[nationalized]] with a cash infusion from the [[Benelux]] countries amounting to €11.2 billion. Fortis' troubles started in the beginning of the year with an announcement that it faced around $1.5bn of losses in the American sub-prime catastrophe. In June, the company announced a selloff of assets to raise €5 bn to improve the liquidity of the organisation. This, however, proved insufficient.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7640247.stm |title=Fortis is 'keystone' European bank |publisher=BBC |author=Ben Shore |date=28 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-01}}</ref> On 6 October 2008, it was announced the French bank BNP Paribas would take over 75 percent of Fortis' activities in Belgium, and 66 percent in [[Luxembourg]], in exchange for the Belgian government becoming the new group's major shareholder.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/la-crise-financiere/article/2008/10/06/bnp-paribas-prend-le-controle-de-fortis-en-belgique-et-au-luxembourg_1103272_1101386.html |title=BNP-Paribas rachète Fortis en Belgique et au Luxembourg |agency=Reuters |language=French |work=Le Monde |accessdate=2009-01-04}}</ref>
However the Belgian government was accused of pressuring shareholders and collapsed over the controversy thus delaying the operation. A new proposition was made on 30 January 2009 with slightly different terms. BNP Paribas would take over 75% of Fortis' banking activities in Belgium and only 10% of the insurance activities in return of what the Belgian government would take 11.7% of BNP Paribas. This agreement would come with a warranty from the Belgian government that it would cover up to €5 billion if more toxic assets were to be discovered.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises/banques-finance/banque/20090130trib000337599/bnp-paribas-bondit-en-bourse-apres-la-renegociation-de-laccord-avec-fortis-.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20090202065514/http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises/banques-finance/banque/20090130trib000337599/bnp-paribas-bondit-en-bourse-apres-la-renegociation-de-laccord-avec-fortis-.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 February 2009 |title=BNP Paribas bondit en Bourse après la renégociation de l'accord avec Fortis |work=La Tribune |date=30 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-04-02 }}</ref> On 30 September 2008 the Belgian, French and Luxembourg governments said they would invest €6.4bn into keeping [[Dexia]], Belgium's second largest bank, afloat.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7643638.stm |title=Second Belgian bank gets bail-out |publisher=BBC News |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-30}}</ref>
In May 2008 industrial output fell in the Netherlands by 6 percent.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2008/07/21/ccview121.xml|title=The global economy is at the point of maximum danger|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=21 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-22 | location=London}}</ref>
On 19 March 2009, the [[INSEE]] announced worse contraction than previously said, predicting a −2.9% set back in growth, and a jobless rate up to 8.8 as soon as June 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2009/03/19/la-france-s-enfonce-dans-une-recession-d-une-ampleur-inedite_1170020_3234.html |title=La France s'enfonce dans une récession d'une ampleur inédite |work=Le Monde }}</ref>
===Portugal=== {{main|Economic history of Portugal}} In the summer of 2010, [[Moody's]] Investors Service cut Portugal's [[sovereign bond]] rating down two notches from an Aa2 to an A1.<ref>[[Bond credit rating]]s</ref> Due to spending on economic stimuli, Portugal's [[debt]] had increased sharply compared to the gross domestic product. Moody noted that the rising debt would weigh heavily on the government's short-term finances.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/10610673.stm |title=Moody's downgrades Portugal debt |publisher=BBC News |date=13 July 2010}}</ref> Earlier in the year, Portugal was one of the countries identified in the [[European sovereign-debt crisis]] as concern spread over increasing government [[Government budget deficit|deficit]] and debt levels in certain countries.
Also in 2010, the country reached a record high unemployment rate of nearly 11%, a figure not seen for over two decades, while the number of [[public servant]]s remained very high.
International [[financial market]]s compelled the Portuguese Government led by Prime Minister [[José Sócrates]], to make radical changes in economic policy, like other European governments had done before. Thus, in September 2010, the Portuguese Government announced a fresh austerity package following other [[Eurozone]] partners, through a series of tax hikes and salary cuts for [[public servant]]s. In 2009, the deficit had been 9.4 percent, one of the highest in the Eurozone and way above the [[European Union]]'s [[Stability and Growth Pact]] three percent limit.
In November 2010, [[risk premium]]s on Portuguese [[bond (finance)|bond]]s hit euro lifetime highs as investors and creditors worried that the country would fail to reign in its budget deficit and debt. The yield on the country's 10-year government bonds reached 7 percent – a level the Portuguese Finance Minister [[Fernando Teixeira dos Santos]] had previously said would require the country to seek financial help from international institutions.
A report published in January 2011 by the [[Diário de Notícias]], a leading Portuguese newspaper, demonstrated that in the period between the [[Carnation Revolution]] in 1974 and 2010, the democratic [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese Republic government]]s had encouraged over expenditure and investment bubbles through unclear public-private partnerships. This had funded numerous ineffective and unnecessary external consultancy and advising committees and firms, allowed considerable [[slippage (finance)|slippage]] in state-managed [[public works]], inflated top management and head officers' bonuses and wages, causing a persistent and lasting recruitment policy that has boosted the number of redundant public servants. The economy has also been damaged by risky [[credit (finance)|credit]], [[public debt]] creation and mismanaged European [[structural and cohesion funds]] for almost four decades. Apparently, the Prime Minister Sócrates's cabinet was not able to forecast or prevent any of this when symptoms first appeared in 2005, and later was incapable of doing anything to ameliorate the situation when the country was on the verge of bankruptcy in 2011.<ref>{{pt icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110108021723/http://dn.sapo.pt/inicio/tv/interior.aspx?content_id=1750097&seccao=Media Grande investigação DN Conheça o verdadeiro peso do Estado], [[Diário de Notícias]] (7 January 2011)</ref>
On 23 March 2011, José Sócrates resigned following passage of a [[no confidence]] motion sponsored by all five opposition parties in parliament over spending cuts and tax increases.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110323-portuguese-parliament-votes-against-austerity-plan-jose-socrates-eurozone |title=Portuguese parliament votes against austerity plan |date=23 March 2011 |publisher=[[France 24]] |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
On 6 April 2011, the resigning Prime Minister announced on the television that the country, facing a status of bankruptcy, would request financial assistance to the [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] (at the time managed by [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn]]) and the [[European Financial Stability Facility]], like Greece and the Republic of Ireland had done before.
In order to accomplish the [[European Union]]/IMF-led rescue plan for Portugal's [[sovereign debt]] crisis, in July and August 2011, the new government led by [[Pedro Passos Coelho]] announced it was going to cut on state spending and increase austerity measures, including public servant wage cuts and additional tax increases.
==Rest of Europe==
The entire economy of the European Union declined by 0.1 percent in the second quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.finfacts.ie/irishfinancenews/article_1014454.shtml|title=Eurozone GDP fell 0.2% in the second quarter of 2008: EU27 GDP fell 0.1%; Economies of Eurozone's Big 4 – Germany, France, Italy and Spain all shrank|publisher=Finfacts Ireland|date=14 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref> A European Commission forecast predicted Germany, Spain and the UK would all enter a recession by the end of the year while France and Italy would have flat growth in the third quarter following second quarter contractions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cf5d0f08-7f49-11dd-a3da-000077b07658.html?nclick_check=1|title=Recession to hit Germany, UK and Spain|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=10 September 2008|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref>
===Denmark=== [[Denmark]] showed a contraction of 0.6 percent in the first quarter of 2008 following a contraction of 0.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2007.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d5d98922-539a-11dd-8dd2-000077b07658.html |title=Early Easter puts Danish economy in recession |work=[[Financial Times]] |date=17 July 2008 |accessdate=2008-07-19}}</ref> Revised data for Denmark, however cancelled the early recession, as GDP ended at +1.0% in Q4 2007 followed by -1.4% in Q1 2008 and +1.5% in Q2 2008. So according to revised data, the Great Recession only started in Denmark in Q3 2008.<ref name="Updated GDP figures">{{cite web|url=http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?QueryId=350#|title=Quarterly National Accounts MetaData: Quarterly Growth Rates of real GDP, change over previous quarter|publisher=OECD|accessdate=20 September 2013}}</ref>
===Latvia=== [[Latvia]]'s gross domestic product fell 0.2 percent in the second quarter following a fall of 0.3 percent in the first quarter.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/feedarticle/7782551 |title=Latvia joins Estonia in recession |work=The Guardian |date=8 September 2008 |accessdate=2008-09-10 |location=London }} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
===Switzerland=== Economists at [[Switzerland]]'s second-largest bank predicted a recession in 2009.<ref>[http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/news/business/Credit_Suisse_agrees_a_recession_looms.html?siteSect=164&sid=10176450&cKey=1231493446000&ty=nd Credit Suisse agrees a recession looms], swissinfo, 9 January 2009</ref>
===Estonia=== [[Estonia]] saw an economic contraction of 0.9 percent in the second quarter of 2008, following a 0.5 percent contraction in the first quarter,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/21c3db62-69a3-11dd-91bd-0000779fd18c.html?nclick_check=1 |title=Estonia becomes first victim of Baltic recession|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=14 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref> but with the revised data showing no recession before Q3 2008.<ref name="Updated GDP figures"/>
Chairwoman of the [[Association of Estonian Food Industry]], Sirje Potisepp, warned the Estonian food industry would probably face bankruptcies citing two major beverage companies in Estonia filing for bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://balticbusinessnews.com/Default2.aspx?ArticleID=29338869-7eed-4c46-bcc6-08237d206351&ref=lastadd|title=Estonian food industry to face bankruptcies-chairwoman|publisher=Baltic Business News|date=19 September 2008|accessdate=2008-09-19}}</ref>
===Slovakia=== [[Slovakia]] was one of only a few countries that retained their high GDP predictions for the year 2008.
===Poland===
[[Poland]] is the only member of the [[European Union]] to have avoided recession, meaning that in 2009 Poland created the most GDP growth in the EU. As of December 2009 the Polish economy had not entered recession nor contracted, while its [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) 2010 GDP growth forecast of 1.9 per cent is expected to be upgraded.<ref name="bloomberg.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=apz_BEuHrNpI |work=Bloomberg |title=Central Europe Risks Downgrades on Worsening Finances (Update1) |date=21 September 2009}}</ref><ref name="bloomberg.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a7k1g_PkuROs# |work=Bloomberg |title=Zloty to Gain, Says LBBW, Most Accurate Forecaster (Update1) |date=9 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aQfKOAzdLHwc |work=Bloomberg |title=Poland's Economic Outlook May Be Raised by IMF, PAP Reports | date=15 December 2009}}</ref> In the second quarter of 2010, growth was at least 3.1 per cent.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE67H02N20100818 |agency=Reuters |title=Polish GDP growth seen at 3.1 pct in Q2-govt official |date=18 August 2010}}</ref> As of 30 August 2010, the EU's GDP growth forecast for Poland in 2010 stands at 2.7 per cent, outperforming the EU average of 1 per cent.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-08-30/polish-gdp-growth-probably-accelerated-on-german-expansion-weaker-zloty.html | work=Bloomberg | first1=Dorota |last1=Bartyzel |first2=Monika |last2=Rozlal |date=30 August 2010 |title=Polish GDP Growth Probably Accelerated on German Expansion, Weaker Zloty |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref> Poland has one of the lowest [[external debt]] rates in the European Union, at just over 320 billion, 46% of its GDP.
===Iceland=== {{Further|2008–2011 Icelandic financial crisis}} The [[Icelandic króna]] has declined 40% against the euro during 2008 and has experienced inflation of 14%.<ref name=WSJ>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122331879240408481?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Iceland Risks Bankruptcy, Leader Says|work=The Wall Street Journal|last=Forelle|first=Charles|date=7 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-07}}</ref> [[Iceland]]'s interest rates have been raised to 15.5% to deal with the high inflation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/financialcrisis/3147866/Financial-crisis-Icelands-dreams-go-up-in-smoke.html|title=Financial crisis: Iceland's dreams go up in smoke|work=The Daily Telegraph|last=Pierce|first=Andrew|date=6 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-07 | location=London}}</ref> This [[devaluation|loss of currency value]] has put pressure on banks in Iceland, which are largely dependent on foreign debt. On 29 September 2008 Iceland's [[Glitnir (bank)|Glitnir]] was effectively nationalized after the Icelandic government acquired 75% of the bank's stock. According to the government the bank "would have ceased to exist" within a few weeks if there had not been intervention.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7641753.stm|title=Iceland nationalises Glitnir bank |publisher=BBC News|date=29 September 2008|accessdate=2008-10-07}}</ref>
Iceland's Prime Minister [[Geir Haarde]] in a television address on 6 October 2008 said credit lines to Icelandic banks had been cut off and that "the Icelandic economy, in the worst case, could be sucked with the banks into the whirlpool and the result could be national bankruptcy" and that the government was looking to other countries for sources of liquidity.<ref name=WSJ /> Iceland's parliament responded to the crisis by approving a bill giving the Government wideranging powers over the banks, including the ability to seize their assets, force them to merge or compel them to sell off their overseas subsidiaries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/banking_and_finance/article4894904.ece|title=Terror as Iceland faces economic collapse|work=The Times|date=7 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-07 | location=London|first=Deirdre|last=Hipwell}}</ref> The parliament went on to seize control and nationalize Iceland's second largest bank, [[Landsbanki]], on 8 October 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/3154116/Financial-crisis-Iceland-nationalises-bank-and-seeks-Russian-loan.html|title=Financial crisis: Iceland nationalises bank and seeks Russian loan|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=8 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-08 | location=London | first=Rowena | last=Mason}}</ref> The Parliament also extended a £400m loan to the nation's largest bank, [[Kaupthing]], in hopes that it would strengthen the institution's [[balance sheet]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/3154116/Financial-crisis-Iceland-nationalises-bank-and-seeks-Russian-loan.html|title=Financial crisis: Iceland nationalises bank and seeks Russian loan|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=8 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-08 | location=London | first=Rowena | last=Mason}}</ref>
On 8 October 2008 UK Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]] announced that the UK government would launch legal action against Iceland, whose government announced that they had no intention of compensating any of the estimated 300,000 UK savers after the nationalization of [[Landsbanki]] and its online brand, [[Icesave dispute|Icesave]].<ref>{{cite web|title=UK govt launching legal action against Iceland |publisher=Citywire |accessdate=2008-10-08 |url=http://www.citywire.co.uk/personal/-/news/markets-companies-and-funds/content.aspx?ID=316803&re=3902&ea=180442 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120803230244/http://www.citywire.co.uk/personal/-/news/markets-companies-and-funds/content.aspx?ID=316803&re=3902&ea=180442 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-08-03 }}</ref> [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Alistair Darling]] announced that the UK government would foot the entire bill, estimated at £4bn,<ref>{{cite web |title=Darling's pledge to Icesave savers |publisher=The Press Association |url=http://ukpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5gIrwQn2oxfrbF2Jz4ehKIqmRQJrw |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012235908/http://ukpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5gIrwQn2oxfrbF2Jz4ehKIqmRQJrw |archivedate=2008-10-12 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Britain vows to protect savers |agency=Agence France-Presse |accessdate=2008-10-08 |url=http://www.news.com.au/business/story/0,27753,24467268-31037,00.html |date=8 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010184234/http://www.news.com.au/business/story/0%2C27753%2C24467268-31037%2C00.html |archivedate=10 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and that he was taking steps to freeze the assets of Landsbanki.<ref>[[BBC news]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/7658518.stm Rescue plan for UK banks unveiled]. Retrieved 2008-10-08</ref> The following day, Darling used the [[Anti-Terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001]] as the basis for seizing the assets of [[Landsbanki|Landsbanki Islands hf]], an Iceland-based bank.<ref>{{cite news|first=Kitty |last=Donaldson |author2=Vina, Gonzalo |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=aXjIA5NzyM5c&refer=uk |title=UK Used Anti-Terrorism Law to Seize Icelandic Bank Assets |publisher=Bloomberg |date=9 October 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-04}}</ref> Icelanders launched an on-line petition drive to protest this action, which is seen as comparing Icelandic banks with [[Al-Qaida]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://forargyll.com/2008/10/icelanders-protest-at-british-use-of-anti-terrorist-legislation-to-freeze-bank-assets-sign-their-e-petition-now/#hide |title=Icelanders protest British use of anti-terrorist law against their banks. Scots sign their e-petition. And Darling knew all along. |publisher=For Argyll |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-04}}</ref>
Iceland's GDP is expected by economists to shrink at least 10 percent as a result of the crisis, putting Iceland by some measure in an [[Depression (economics)|economic depression]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/crisis-deepens-for-iceland-as-last-of-big-three-banks-is-nationalised-956711.html|title=Crisis deepens for Iceland as last of 'big three' banks is nationalised|work=[[The Independent]]|date=10 October 2008|accessdate=2008-10-12 | location=London | first1=David | last1=Prosser}}</ref>
On 27 January 2009 the government collapsed.
===Hungary=== On 10 October 2008, the [[Forint]] dropped by 10%.<ref>[https://archive.is/20090112094604/http://www.boursorama.com/international/detail_actu_intern.phtml?news=5958539]</ref> The [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) announced on 16 October that it was bailing out [[Hungary]] with a 5 billion euro (US$6.7 billion) loan facility, just days after the [[Hungarian Finance Ministry]] said it was seeking consultations with the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) about a possible support package. The ECB's unprecedented move in bailing out a non-euro state underlines the crisis unraveling in Hungary and its possible impact on the rest of Central Europe. Several players will be affected, but at particular risk are the [[Austria]]n banks which invested so heavily in the region. A potential serious hiccup of the Austrian banks could mark a significant blow to Europe's already troubled banking system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stratfor.com/analysis/20081020_hungary_hungarian_financial_crisis_impact_austrian_banks |title=Hungary: The Hungarian Financial Crisis’ Impact On Austrian Banks |publisher=Stratfor }}</ref>
Hungary, which joined the European Union in 2004, has been hit hard by the current financial crisis due to its heavy dependence on [[foreign capital]] to finance its economy and has one of the biggest public [[Government budget deficit|deficit]]s in the EU. Prior to the international bailout, the government had feared the worst, including a collapse of the [[forint|national currency]], Prime Minister [[Ferenc Gyurcsány]] said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/1225823530.76 |accessdate=6 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112230522/http://www.eubusiness.com/news-eu/1225823530.76 |archivedate=12 January 2009 }}</ref>
In November Hungary has received a $25 billion cash injection from the International Monetary Fund to save it from financial collapse.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FqbHk4Zhh6U |title=Hungary economy – November 15, 2008 |publisher=YouTube |date=19 November 2008}}</ref> In December, the IMF transferred $5 billion and the ECB $2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://index.hu/gazdasag/magyar/imfkep3480/ |title=Index – Gazdaság – Még borúsabb prognózisra készül az IMF |publisher=Index.hu |date=30 June 1999}}</ref>
===Bulgaria===
On 10 June 2009 Bulgarian authorities declared the country was officially in recession with its economy shrinking 4.2 percent from January to June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seenews.com/news/latestnews/bulgaria_sh1gdpshrinksbyreal4_2_y_y-103056/ |accessdate=31 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716035154/http://www.seenews.com/news/latestnews/bulgaria_sh1gdpshrinksbyreal4_2_y_y-103056/ |archivedate=16 July 2011 }}</ref> The Bulgarian economy contracted by 4.8 percent year-on-year in the second quarter for the first time in 12 years. Unemployment is rising rapidly. The agriculture sector registered a 6.6-percent decline in activity in the second quarter of 2009 compared to the same period last year, while industry shrank by 9.8 percent. The services sector meanwhile grew by 0.3 percent. Bulgaria's imports during the first half of this year compared to January–June 2008 contracted by 24.2 percent and exports declined by 18.2 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsi.bg/Gdp/ExpressGDP2009q2.pdf |accessdate=31 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901194519/http://www.nsi.bg/Gdp/ExpressGDP2009q2.pdf |archivedate=1 September 2009 }}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== [[File:Birmingham Northern Rock bank run 2007.jpg|thumb|250px|People queuing on 15 September 2007 outside a [[Northern Rock]] bank branch in the United Kingdom, to withdraw money from their accounts.]] The economy of the United Kingdom has also been hit by rising oil prices and the credit crisis. Sir [[Win Bischoff]], chairman of [[Citigroup]], spoke of his belief that house prices in Britain would fall constantly for two years from the end of 2007.{{when|date=February 2014}} The [[Ernst & Young]] Item club predicted growth of only 1.5 percent in 2008, slowing to 1 percent in 2009. They also predicted consumer spending would slow to only 0.2 percent, and forecast a two-year drop in investment. The [[Institute of Directors]]’ quarterly business opinion survey showed business optimism at its lowest level since the survey began in 1996.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article4363962.ece|title=UK economy heads for ‘horror movie’|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|date=20 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-20 | location=London | first1=David | last1=Smith | first2=Dominic | last2=Oconnell}}</ref>
Deputy Governor of the [[Bank of England]], [[John Gieve]], said inflation would accelerate "well over" 4 percent while economic growth is "slowing fast." Bank of England Governor [[Mervyn King (economist)|Mervyn King]] said there may be "an odd quarter or two of negative growth," following the first quarter of 2009. Gieve said he couldn't rule out the UK economy heading into a recession, adding the economy was "quite a long way" from the end of the slowdown.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=a_1GKV39Cue8&refer=uk|title=Gieve Sees UK Inflation Accelerating `Well Over' 4%|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=18 July 2008|accessdate=2008-07-19}}</ref>
Nationwide, the UK's biggest building society, warned the UK could head into a recession after house prices in July 2008 fell 8.1 percent from the previous year. Housing prices declined by 1.7 percent in July, double the decline recorded in June. Standard & Poor's said on 30 July 2008 that 70,000 homeowners were in [[negative equity]] and it could rise to 1.7 million or about one in six homeowners in the UK based on an expected 17 percent decline into 2009. The Bank of England reported that mortgage approvals fell by a record of nearly 70 percent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/money/property_and_mortgages/article4433925.ece|title=Nationwide warns of recession as house price drop doubles|work=The Times|date=31 July 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11 | location=London|first=Deirdre|last=Hipwell}}</ref>
In [[Northern Ireland]], house sales saw a fall of some 50 per cent according to a survey by the University of Ulster/Bank of Ireland and housing prices fell on average by 4 percent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2008/0806/1217923985168.html|title=House sales in North decline by about half|work=[[The Irish Times]]|date=6 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref> British manufacturing activity declined by the most in almost a decade in July, the third consecutive month of declines.
The number of companies that went into administration in May–July 2008 was 938, an increase of 60 percent compared with the same period in 2007. The number of company liquidations in the second quarter of 2008 rose to 3,689, a 16 percent increase and the highest quarterly figure in five years. House builders expected the number of houses built in 2008 in England and Wales to be the lowest since 1924. The declines were seen as an indication the United Kingdom had a high chance of entering a recession.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/08/01/business/EU-Britain-Economy.php|title=UK economic data points to recession|work=International Herald Tribune|date=1 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref> Factory production in the UK dropped 0.5 percent in June 2008 when twelve out of 13 categories of factory production fell. The economic output of the UK was reported to have increased by just 0.2 percent in the second quarter 2008, the joint-slowest pace since 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601068&sid=amXGoLZbo2qk&refer=home|title=U.K. Services Contract, Factory Production Drops|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=5 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
The value of sterling relative to other currencies dropped by around 30%.
The [[Office for National Statistics]] later gave a revised number saying growth in the British economy was at zero, the worst since the second quarter of 1992.<ref>{{cite news |title=Data confirms economy shrinking | date = 26 November 2008 | publisher=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7749729.stm}}</ref> The current slowdown has ended 16 years of continuous economic growth, the longest period of economic expansion in Britain since the 19th century.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/business/news/display.var.2432004.0.Recession_fears_are_stoked_as_UK_economy_grinds_to_a_halt.php|title=Recession fears are stoked as UK economy grinds to a halt|work=[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]|date=23 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-23}}</ref> A report from the National Institute for Economic and Social Research said the economy contracted by 0.1 percent in the period from May to July 2008 and 0.2 percent from June to August 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601102&sid=alCAr4RDjjUc&refer=uk|title=U.K. Economy Contracts, Edges Toward a Recession|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=10 September 2008|accessdate=2008-09-11}}</ref>
A voter backlash due to the personal financial effects of the global credit crunch was widely attributed by politicians of the [[Labour Party (UK)|United Kingdom Labour Party]], which had been in power since 1997, as the reason their political fortunes took a dramatic downturn through May 2008, with a succession of defeats in by-elections and the London Mayoral election, and the worst opinion poll result in their history.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}} Political opponents countered this apparent excuse by pointing to the fact that the incumbent Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]], who had taken office in June 2007 just before the crisis broke, had been the country's '[[Chancellorship of Gordon Brown|Iron Chancellor]]', and had allegedly not ensured the country had sufficient monetary reserves to be able to lower taxes and ease the burden on voters, despite overseeing one of the longest sustained periods of economic growth in the country's history. In August 2008 the party also faced calls to impose a [[Windfall Tax (United Kingdom)|windfall tax]] on the utility companies, who were reaping record profits due to the fuel crisis, perceived as in bad taste given rising food and fuel prices.
On 17 September 2008, news emerged that the banking and insurance group [[HBOS]] (Halifax Bank of Scotland) was in merger talks with [[Lloyds TSB]] about creating a UK retail banking giant worth £30bn. The move received the backing of the British government which stated that it will over-rule any claims from the competition authorities.
According to the [[Office for National Statistics]] unemployment claims in August 2008 increased by 32,500 to reach 904,900. The wider Labour Force Survey measure found joblessness rose by 81,000 to 1.72 million between May and July, the largest increase since 1999.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/sep/17/unemploymentdata.recession|title=Sharp rise in unemployment claimants|last=Hopkins|first=Kathryn|work=The Guardian|date=17 September 2008|accessdate=2008-09-19 | location=London}}</ref>
In September 2008, British bank [[Bradford & Bingley]]'s £20 billion savings business was acquired by Spanish bank [[Grupo Santander]]. While its retail deposit business along with its branch network will be sold to Santander. The mortgage book, personal loan book, headquarters, treasury assets and its wholesale liabilities will be taken into public ownership.
From 1 December 2008, the UK Government made the decision to cut [[Taxation in the United Kingdom#Value added tax|VAT]] from 17.5% to 15% for 13 months in an attempt to encourage a big spend from UK shoppers before Christmas, and again in the run-up to Christmas 2009.
On 4 December 2008, the [[Bank of England]] cut interest rates from 3% to 2%, which amounted to the lowest level since 1951.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7764741.stm|title=Bank cuts UK rates to 57-year low |publisher=BBC|date=4 December 2008|accessdate=2008-12-04}}</ref>
On 8 January 2009, the Bank of England reduced rates even further, from 2% to 1.5%, the lowest level in the its 315-year history.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}}
On 23 January 2009, Government figures from the [[Office for National Statistics]] showed that the UK was officially in recession for the first time since 1991; with a 1.5% fall in gross domestic product during the final quarter of 2008 being the sharpest for 28 years.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7846266.stm|title=UK in recession as economy slides |publisher=BBC|date=23 January 2009|accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref>
On 5 February 2009 interest rates were cut further from 1.5% to 1%.
A February 2009 research on the main British [[insurers]] showed that most of them are not considering officially raising [[insurance premium]]s for the year 2009, in spite of the 20% raise predictions made by [[The Daily Telegraph]] or [[The Daily Mirror]]. However, it is expected that the capital liquidity will become an issue and determine increases, having their capital tied up in investments yielding smaller dividends, corroborated with the £644 million underwriting losses suffered in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abi.org.uk/BookShop/ResearchReports/Key%20facts%202008.pdf |accessdate=19 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090407065610/http://www.abi.org.uk/BookShop/ResearchReports/Key%20facts%202008.pdf |archivedate=7 April 2009 }}</ref>
On 5 March 2009, the Bank of England cut interest rates yet again, from 1% to 0.5%. The same week, it announced that it would begin a policy of [[quantitative easing]], printing up to £150 billion of new money.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/pensions/4950466/Retirement-plans-of-millions-of-Britons-at-risk-after-Bank-of-England-prints-money.html|title=Retirement plans of millions of Britons at risk after Bank of England prints money|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=2009-06-03 | location=London | first=Edmund | last=Conway | date=6 March 2009}}</ref>
Figures published in March 2009 by the Bank of England revealed that over $1 trillion in foreign holdings had been withdrawn from UK banks between spring and the end of 2008, representing a huge loss of confidence in UK financial institutions.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/run-on-uk-sees-foreign-investors-pull-1-trillion-out-of-the-city-1639413.html|title=Run on UK sees foreign investors pull $1 trillion out of the City|work=The Independent|accessdate=2009-06-03 | location=London | first=Sean | last=O'grady | date=7 March 2009}}</ref>
By November 2008, unemployment had risen to over 1.8 million (compared to less than 1.7 million at the start of the year and less than 1.5 million as recently as 2005) and by early 2009 had exceeded 2 million, the highest since 1996. It was feared that unemployment could reach 3 million during 2010 – a level not seen since the 1980s. However, the end of the recession in the United Kingdom was declared on 26 January 2010, by which time unemployment stood at nearly 2.5 million. A peak of almost 2.7 million was reached in late 2011.
A report by the [[Office for National Statistics|ONS]] produced in March 2009 stated that the UK economy shrank by 1.6 percent during the last quarter of 2008, with a 1% drop in household spending. A further decline of up to 4% GDP during 2009 was predicted.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1165160/British-economy-shrinking-faster-expected-Alistair-Darling-admits-Were-guilty.html?ITO=1490|title=British economy shrinking faster than expected as Alistair Darling admits: We're all guilty|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=2009-03-27 | location=London | first=Benedict | last=Brogan | date=27 March 2009}}</ref>
In April 2009, it was reported that first quarter GDP had shrunk by 1.9 percent, with a prediction of a 4.1 percent drop for the year. The largest contributor to this figure was manufacturing output, which fell by 6.9 percent over the quarter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/cci/nugget.asp?id=192 |title=ONS Home |publisher=Statistics.gov.uk }}</ref>
In May 2009, [[Standard & Poor's]] cut its rating outlook for the UK to negative.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ousiv/idUSTRE54K2A320090521 | agency=Reuters | title=S&P cuts UK's rating outlook to negative | date=21 May 2009}}</ref> Official figures also showed that British public borrowing hit a record high for the month of April, the first month of the new tax year – net public borrowing came in at £8.5bn in April 2009, compared to April 2008's figure of £1.8bn
In June 2009, the figure for the first quarter GDP drop was revised downwards from 1.9 to 2.4 percent, with economic output falling 4.1% from the previous year. Revised figures also showed that the recession began in Q2 of 2008, rather than Q3 of 2008 as previously reported.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8125898.stm|title=Sharp contraction for UK economy|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-30 | date=30 June 2009}}</ref>
In the 3 months to May 2009, the unemployment rate showed a record quarterly rise of 281,000 to stand at 2.38 million – which represented 7.6% of the working population. In the three months to June, the number of job vacancies fell to a record low of 429,000, down by 35,000 from the previous quarter.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8151017.stm|title=Record rise in UK jobless total |publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-07-15 | date=15 July 2009}}</ref>
By the end of June 2009, the public sector debt stood at £798.8 billion, equivalent to 56.6% of GDP, the highest percentage since records began in 1974. This compared to £641.4 billion or 44.4% of GDP in June 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/pdfdir/psf0709.pdf |format=pdf |title=Public sector finances |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605080615/http://www.statistics.gov.uk/pdfdir/psf0709.pdf |archivedate=2011-06-05 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref> The figure is expected to rise still higher when the costs of bailing out [[Royal Bank of Scotland Group|RBS]] and [[Lloyds Banking Group|LLoyds Bank]] are added.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/business/?jp=eykfsnojeyoj|title=UK government debt now at 56.6% of output|publisher=breakingnews.ie|accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref>
By August 2009, UK unemployment stood at more than 2.4 million, the highest since 1995. The Bank of England announced that due to the deepening recession in the UK, it would be extending its quantitative easing program to a new total of £175 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a4aYFAQngM6w|title=BOE Extends Bond Purchases After Recession Deepened|publisher=Bloomberg | date=6 August 2009}}</ref> In November 2009, The Bank of England announced it would be adding a further £25 billion in continuation of quantitative easing in assisting the UK economy through the recession.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8344189.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Extra £25bn to stimulate economy | date=5 November 2009 | accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref>
In December 2009, it was revealed that the UK's unemployment total stood at almost 2.5 million – another monthly rise and the highest level for 15 years – but the number of people claiming unemployment benefit had actually fallen by more than 6,000. By this stage, the UK was one of the last major economies still in recession.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8427237.stm BBC News: UK out of Recession] Access Date 26 January 2010</ref> However, on 26 February 2010 it was revealed that the UK economy had grown by 0.3% within the last quarter of 2009 and the UK was out of recession.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8538293.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=UK economic growth revised upward | date=26 February 2010 | accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref>
However, many economists were still unsure of the situation<ref>{{cite news|last=Conway |first=Edmund |url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/finance/edmundconway/100003306/bad-good-news-on-the-economy/ |title=The Telegraph: Bad Good News on the Economy |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=26 January 2010 |location=London}}</ref> – the relatively small drop in unemployment benefit claimants could be attributed to seasonal jobs, and with a general election imminent, the government had every reason to present the best economic picture possible. Other factors which could have produced an artificially high growth rate included the end of the "cash-for-clunkers" car replacement scheme, and the ending of a VAT cut from 15% to 17.5% in January causing many consumers to push forward their purchases. In addition, £200 billion had been pumped into the economy via QE, and the central bank rate had been held at almost 0% for most of the year. Thus although official figures showed that the UK had indeed exited recession fears of a double-dip recession remained. According to the IMF, the UK economy had grown slower than that of Portugal or Italy in 2010.
The popularity of Britain's [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] government, led by prime minister [[Gordon Brown]] since June 2007, slumped dramatically during 2008 and 2009, with low rankings in opinion polls, dismal performances in local and European elections, and losing several seats in parliamentary by-elections. The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] opposition, led by [[David Cameron]], won the most votes and seats in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]], but fell short of an overall majority, and agreed a coalition with the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] in order to form a new government. The new government faced numerous economic challenges, namely re-establishing economic growth, reducing the national deficit and reducing unemployment, not to mention a host of social problems, many of which had been intensified as a result of the recession.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/default.stm]</ref>
===Romania===
Despite high economic growth in 2008 (8.7%), [[Romania]] was affected very hard by the crisis, analysts forecasting a contraction of 8–9% for 2009, as the new government established in the late 2008 was unable to take any anti-crisis measures.
[[Economy of Romania|Romania's economy]] has been one of the hardest hit in Europe. The country's trade deficit fell by more than 60 percent during the first half of 2009, but not because of exports taking off, but due to business bankruptcies and unemployment decreasing consumption.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sr.se/cgi-bin/ekot/artikel.asp?Artikel=3022205 |archive-url=http://wayback.vefsafn.is/wayback/20100312164356/http%3A//www.sr.se/cgi%2Dbin/ekot/artikel.asp?Artikel%3D3022205 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-03-12 |title=Svårt ekonomiskt läge för Rumänien – Ekot |publisher=Sr.se }}</ref>

maintained that Putin was "at least partially responsible for it":<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2004/06/b99061.html The Putin Paradox] by [[Michael McFaul]] 24 June 2004</ref> a series of fundamental reforms had been implemented, including a [[flat income tax]] of 13 percent, a reduced profits tax, and new land and legal codes.
In October 2008 Russia emerged as one of the countries hardest-hit by the [[Late 2000s recession|global economic crisis]],<ref name="Hardest">{{cite news |title=Russia among hardest-hit in economic meltdown|work=[[USA Today]] |date=10 October 2008 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-10-09-russia_N.htm|accessdate=2009-02-07 | first1=Tai | last1=Adelaja | first2=Jeffrey | last2=Stinson}}</ref><ref name="AAsl">{{cite news|author=[[Anders Åslund]]|url=http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=27959 |title=Crisis Puts Putinomics to the Test|publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=29 December 2008 |accessdate=2009-02-11}}</ref> the stock market crash having been precipitated by [[Vladimir Putin]]'s verbal attack on [[Mechel]] in July that year and Russian peacekeepers' aid to the South Ossetian Republic in August.<ref name="PutCrash">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/now-financial-crisis-takes-toll-in-russia-933890.html|title=Now financial crisis takes toll in Russia |work=[[The Independent]]|date=17 September 2008|accessdate=2009-02-07 | location=London | first=Shaun | last=Walker}}</ref><ref name="JShelton">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB122039907604792875.html |title=The Market Will Punish Putinism |work=The Wall Street Journal|date=3 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908082736/http://online.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB122039907604792875.html |archivedate=2008-09-08 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref>
In 2008, Russia's benchmark [[RTS Index|RTS share index]] lost 72.4 percent, ranking it as an unusual performer of all major emerging markets.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/12/31/russian-index-dropped-724_n_154478.html |title=Russian Index Dropped 72.4 Percent in 2008 |work=Huffington Post | first=Dave |last=Burdick |date=31 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/article/1016/42/374403.htm|title=Rescuing Russia From Collapse|date=10 February 2009|work=[[The Moscow Times]]|accessdate=2009-02-11}}</ref>
In January 2009, Russia's State Statistics Service released data, according to which the Russian [[industrial production]] slumped in December 2008 by 10.3 percent after falling 8.7 percent in November that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/article/1009/42/373886.htm|title=Industrial Output Falls By 10.3% in December|date=26 January 2009|work=[[The Moscow Times]]|accessdate=2009-02-12}}</ref>
However, the Russian main stock exchange index has doubled by autumn 2009, compared to the end 2008, and, by the end of 2009, has almost reached the pre-crisis levels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/russias-rts-index-doubles-as-oil-lures-investors-2009-09-29 |title=Russia's RTS index doubles as oil lures investors – Emerging Markets Report |publisher=MarketWatch }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rts.ru/en/index/stat/dailyhistory.html?code=RTSI |title=Daily History of the RTS Index (RTSI) — RTS Stock Exchange | Indices |publisher=Rts.ru }}</ref>
===Sweden===
[[Sweden]] has not been severely affected, and no banks or financial institutions have had real trouble. However, some effects have been visible, mostly based on distrust and similar psychological mechanisms. The stockmarket has declined heavily, because of influence from New York and other markets. Some banks, especially [[Swedbank]] had invested heavily in US housing bonds.
The banks did not trust each other well and the difference between the [[Interbank lending market|interbank interest rate]] and the state interest rate has gone up at least 1%. The housing loan interest rates have gone up even further. The global sales especially of cars has gone down, forcing the Swedish car industry to lay off staff and contractors. The increased fear of enduring recession and the increased financing costs have lowered company investments and private consumption.
Sweden entered recession after a two consecutive quarter of economic contraction. Sweden's economy showed zero growth in the second quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stockholmnews.com/more.aspx?NID=1508|title=Sweden heading for recession|publisher=Stockholm News|date=6 August 2008|accessdate=2008-08-17}}</ref> The Swedish GDP contracted by 0,1% during both the second and third quarters of 2008.<ref>.[http://www.latribune.fr/actualites/economie/international/20081128trib000315353/la-suede-entre-a-son-tour-en-recession.html La Suède entre à son tour en récession], [[La Tribune]] (28 November 2008) {{fr icon}}</ref> [[economy of Sweden|Sweden's economy]] sank into recession in the third quarter of 2008. In October retail sales dropped 0.6 percent in the month, and household consumption fell 0.2 percent in the third quarter.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9a691870-bdb8-11dd-bba1-0000779fd18c.html?nclick_check=1|title=Sweden slides into recession| work= Financial Times|date=29 November 2008}}</ref> The [[Riksbank]] offered 60 billion kronor ($7.71 billion) in loans to financial firms at an auction, after having opened credit facilities to maintain the liquidity in the banking sector.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.se/15522/20081107/|title=Riksbank announces loans to Sweden's financial sector| publisher= The Local|date= 7 November 2008}}</ref> At the beginning of December, the government launched a financial stability package to rev up the economy,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9295bca0-9e7a-11dd-98bd-000077b07658.html|title= Stockholm backs banks with $205bn| work= Financial Times|date=20 October 2008}}</ref> while the central bank, urged by the [[OECD]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5414b238-c12f-11dd-831e-000077b07658.html|title= OECD urges Sweden to make deep rate cut| work= Financial Times|date=3 December 2008}}</ref> cut down its interest rates to 2%<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5b01952c-c1e1-11dd-a350-000077b07658.html|title=Sweden slashes rates to 2%| work= Financial Times|date=4 December 2008}}</ref>
===Ukraine=== {{Further|2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis}}
Ratings agency [[Fitch Ratings|Fitch]] warned [[Ukraine]] could be headed for a [[currency crisis]] as economic fundamentals deteriorate and the country enters [[2008 Ukrainian political crisis|another period of political uncertainty]]. Fitch said the current account deficit was likely to widen further as prices of gas imports rise and prices of its steel exports fall and said Ukraine was likely to need to borrow more at a time when global debt markets have ground to a virtual standstill. Ukraine's central bank chief, [[Petro Poroshenko]], said he saw no need to intervene to protect the currency.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/feedarticle/7826958 |title=Fitch cuts Ukraine outlook on risk of currency crisis |work=The Guardian |date=25 September 2008 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929053021/http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/feedarticle/7826958 |archivedate=2008-09-29 |accessdate=2013-09-12}}</ref>
[[Ukraine]] was hit heavy by the economic crisis of 2008, analysts say the plights of Ukraine are slumping steel prices, local banking problems and the [[Russia–Ukraine gas disputes#Disputes of 2007-2008|cutting of Russian gas supply in January 2009]].<ref name="Unian">[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-291102.html Trade in Ukraine hrvynia drying up amid crisis], [[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency]] (19 December 2008)</ref> Key industries such as metallurgy and machine building are laying off workers, and real wages have started to fall for the first time in a decade.<ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews[swords]=8fd5893941d69d0be3f378576261ae3e&tx_ttnews[any_of_the_words]=Ukraine&tx_ttnews[tt_news]=34278&tx_ttnews[backPid]=7&cHash=0b4d5d9e67 Hard Times for Ukrainian Banks, Central Bank Chairman Under Fire], [[The Jamestown Foundation]] (17 December 2008)</ref>
===Norway=== The Norwegian government pension fund suffered an investment loss of $92 billion during 2008. However, the overall value of the fund rose due to oil sales and currency movements.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7937360.stm|title=Norway pension fund loses $92bn|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-11-03 | date=11 March 2009}}</ref>
===Croatia=== With economic growth ceasing by the end in 2008, the [[Croatia]]n economy entered a crisis that exposed numerous structural issues and unsustainable growth mechanisms, causing the period of instability to fester until as late as 2015.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.jutarnji.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/sanaderu-je-trebalo-vise-od-godinu-dana-da-prizna-kako-je-hrvatska-u-banani/6448993/ | language = Croatian | newspaper = [[Jutarnji list]] | date = 10 August 2017 | accessdate = 1 November 2018 | title = Deset godina krize - Sanaderu je trebalo više od godinu dana da prizna kako je Hrvatska ‘u banani’ | first = Andrea | last = Koščec | trans-title = Ten years of crisis - Sanader took more than a year to admit Croatia is 'screwed'}}</ref>
The country was still in the midst of what was effectively a six-year long recession when it [[2013 enlargement of the European Union|became a member of the European Union]] in July 2013.
The recession had contributed to the fall of the [[Cabinet of Ivo Sanader II]] and its replacement with the [[Cabinet of Jadranka Kosor]]. It was interrupted by a period of stagnation in 2011, that nevertheless led to the election of the [[Cabinet of Zoran Milanović]], yet the economy soon returned to recession, in which it remained until the end of 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://dnevnik.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/ovako-je-pocela-recesija-u-hrvatskoj-drzava-je-u-banani---374438.html | language = Croatian | work = Dnevnik.hr | publisher = [[Nova TV (Croatia)]] | date = 28 February 2015 | accessdate = 1 November 2018 | title = Hrvatska 'Davne' 2008. godine - Recesija u Hrvatskoj od prvog dana - 'Bez dramatike, visimo o niti' | trans-title = Croatia of 'ancient' 2008 - Recession in Croatia from day one - 'Without being dramatic, we are hanging by a thread'}}</ref>
==European Economic Recovery Plan== {{Main|2008 European Union stimulus plan}} In November 2008, the [[European Commission]] presented the [[2008 European Union stimulus plan|European Economic Recovery Plan]],<ref>Communication from the Commission and the European Council, [http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=COM:2008:0800:FIN:EN:HTML A European Economic Recovery Plan], 26 November 2008</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20120708050823/http://ec.europa.eu/research/transport/info/article_9086_en.html]</ref> a plan of 200 billion euros (1.2% of GDP) to fight against the consequences of the economic crisis in the [[European Union]].<ref>[[European Commission]], [http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/08/1771 The Commission launches a major Recovery Plan for growth and jobs, to boost demand and restore confidence in the European economy], 26 November 2008</ref> In reality, the plan is a series of national measures to be implemented by each government, without much coherency between the policies. The measures included incentives to investment, tax cuts and social measures.
===Electromobility=== [[Electrification of transport]] ([[electromobility]]) figures prominently in the Green Car Initiative (GCI), included in the European Economic Recovery Plan. [[Directorate-General for Mobility and Transport (European Commission)|DG TREN]] is supporting a large European "electromobility" project on [[electric vehicle]]s and related infrastructure with a total budget of around €50million as part of the Green Car Initiative.<ref name="ec.europa.eu">{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/urban/vehicles/road/electric_en.htm |title=Electric vehicles – Transport |publisher=European Commission |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319033116/http://ec.europa.eu/transport/urban/vehicles/road/electric_en.htm |archivedate=19 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
