{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} [[File:Pavithrotsavam.jpg|thumb|200px|Lord [[Malayappa swami]] with consorts as seen during the Pavitrotsavam festival. Prominently seen on the Lord and his consorts are the ''Pavitra'' garlands]] '''Pavitrotsavam''' is an annual ritual in the [[Tirumala Venkateswara Temple]], [[Andhra Pradesh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srivenkatesa.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=493:history-of-pavitrotsavam&catid=34:temple-history&Itemid=117| title=Pavitrotsavam}}</ref><ref name='hindu'>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2004/08/22/stories/2004082204370300.htm| title=`Pavitrotsavam' at Tirumala from August 28 |publisher=[[The Hindu]] | date=2004-08-22 | accessdate=2007-05-12}}</ref> Pavitrotsava is derived from the combination of two words ''Pavitra'' (holy) and ''utsava'' (festival). This utsava is penitential as well as propitiatory and its main objective is to get rid of the evil that might have been caused due to omissions and commissions in the performance of various rituals throughout the year. The festival is also known as ''Dosha Nivaarana'' (error correction),''Sarva Yajna Phalapradha'' (The One ritual that equals the holiness of rites all year long),''Sarva Doshopasamana'' (Removal of all errors), ''Sarva Tushtikara'', ''Sarvakaamapradha'', ''Sarvalokasantida''.<ref name='srivenkatesa.org'>{{cite web|url=http://www.srivenkatesa.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=493:history-of-pavitrotsavam&catid=34:temple-history&Itemid=117|title=Srivenkatesa.org|work=srivenkatesa.org}}</ref>
==Reference to holy scripts== The Jayakhya Samhita explains that pavitra protects one from evil. The puranas prescribe ''Pavitra Aaropana'' (adorning the deity with ''pavitra'' - sanctified garlands of thread), as an integral part of the rituals during the worship of Lord Vishnu. The ''Agni Purana'' specifies that the first day of a lunar fortnight either in the beginning of the month of Aashada or the end of the Krithika should be chosen for performing pavitrotsava. The ''Garuda Purana'' says that this rite should be done on the 12th day of the dark or bright fortnight.
==Rituals== [[File:Pavithrotsavam ritual.jpg|250px|left|thumb|Priests carrying ''Pavitra'' garlands during the Pavitrotsavam festival]] In Tirumala, the Pavitrotsavam ritual is conducted on ''Sravana shuddha [[dashami]]'' day.<ref name = 'Tirumalatemple'>{{cite book |first=Dr N Ramesan|title=The Tirumala Temple |year=1981 |publisher=[[Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams]]|location=[[Tirumala]]}}</ref>
`Ankurarpanam' or the sowing of nine type of holy seeds in earthen containers is undertaken on the day preceding the festival. This ritual signifies the beginning of festival in the temple. This is followed by recital of vedas in a ritual called ''Mritsangrahana''. The Ankurarpana and Mritsangrahana rituals are identical to those performed during Brahmotsava. Veda recitation is started after the Mritsangrahana ritual and this recitation of the Vedas concludes on the third day. Through the chanting of the vedas, ''Aavahana'' (Invoking) is done for Lord Vishnu in the Pradhana Kumbha (first of the holy container). There are 16 other Kumbhas surrounding this Pradhana Kumbha and it is believed that the various mantras which are recited infuse voice vibrations that have great religious and spiritual force. The ''Pradhana khumba'' is taken to the [[Tirumala Dhruva Bera|main deity]] on the concluding day and the augmented spiritual power is believed to be transmitted to the Moola Vigraha (Kumbha Aavaahanam).<ref name='hindu'/> The rituals on the three days include ''Thirumanjanam'' and ''Homam'' (prayer to sacrificial fire) to the main deity as well as primary idols of Lord Venkateswara.
''Pavitra''s, the garlands made from special thread are taken in a procession and used to decorate Lord [[Malayappa swami]] and his consorts on the second day. In the evening of the second day, the idols are taken on a procession around the four mada streets.
During the three-day festival, [[Arjitha Seva]]s like ''Kalyanotsavam'', ''Arjitha Brahmotsavam'', ''Arjitha Vasanothsavam'', ''Sahasara Deepalankarana Seva'', ''Dolotsavam'' are cancelled while the morning rituals are held.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srivenkatesa.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=493:history-of-pavitrotsavam&catid=34:temple-history&Itemid=117| title=The `Pavitrotsavam' at Tirumala }}</ref>
==History of festival== The origin of Pavitrotsavam in Tirumala dates back to 1463 A.D. The stone inscription found on the northern wall of the Vagapadi verandah in the first ''Prakaara'' of the Tirumala temple gives a very detailed account.<ref name='hindu'/> The festival was instituted by Saluva Malliah deva Raja during the time of Saluva Narasimha.<ref name='Tirumalatemple'/> The inscription refers even to the items of expenditure to be incurred in connection with the celebration of ''Pavitra Tirunal''.<ref name='hindu'/>
The festival is believed to have been conducted till 1562 A.D. after which the ritual was stopped. The reason for discontinuing such an important festival is not recorded and remains unknown. [[Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams|TTD]] decided to revive the ritual that is followed in all Vishnu temples and the festival has been on the annual calendar from 1962 onwards.
==Devotee Participation== Pavitrotsavam is an ''Arjita Seva'' - participation by payment to the Lord. TTD sells tickets to this service on the second and third days. Each ticket allows two persons and the primary ticket holder is given 10 dosas and Pongal on the second day and 10 dosas and Pongal, 6 vadas and ''vastram'' (one silk angavastram and one cotton blouse) on the third day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tirumala.org/sevas_per.htm|title=TTD Periodic Sevas|accessdate=2007-05-12|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514214720/http://www.tirumala.org/sevas_per.htm|archivedate=2007-05-14|df=}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} [[File:Rahima Banu.jpg|thumb|In 1975, two-year-old Rahima Banu contracted last known case of naturally-occurring variola major Smallpox.]]
'''Rahima Banu Begum''' ({{lang-bn| রহিমা বানু বেগুম}}; born 16 October 1972)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-YeAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Rahima+Banu%22&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIXTAL|title=A Chance to Live|last=Goodfield|first=June|date=1 January 1991|publisher=Macmillan Publishing Company|year=|isbn=9780025446557|location=|pages=4|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> is the last known person to have been infected with naturally occurring ''Variola major'' [[smallpox]], the more deadly variety of the disease.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MxqIAjXv4ggC&pg=PA112&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=Scourge: The Once and Future Threat of Smallpox|last=Tucker|first=Jonathan B.|date=9 December 2016|publisher=Grove Press|year=|isbn=9780802139399|location=|pages=112|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ptv-wmL5NJAC&pg=PA157&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIcjAP#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=Inside the Outbreaks: The Elite Medical Detectives of the Epidemic Intelligence Service|last=Pendergrast|first=Mark|date=1 January 2010|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|year=|isbn=0151011206|location=|pages=157|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
== The disease == The case was reported on 16 October 1975,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z2zMKsc1Sn0C&pg=PA172-IA10&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIRDAH#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=The Greatest Killer: Smallpox in History|last=Hopkins|first=Donald R.|date=15 September 2002|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=9780226351681|language=en}}</ref> when Banu was three years old,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lU4TAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT17&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIVzAK#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=The Cure in the Code: How 20th Century Law is Undermining 21st Century Medicine|last=Huber|first=Peter|date=12 November 2013|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=0465069819|language=en}}</ref> and living in the village of [[Kuralia]] on [[Bhola Island]] in the [[Bangladesh]] district of [[Barisal District|Barisal]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WnjlBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA62&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIZTAN#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|last=Kelley|first=Bob|date=16 February 2015|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|year=|isbn=9781439649466|location=|pages=62|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> Her case was reported by an eight-year-old girl, Bilkisunnessa,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SgTkBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA216-IA8&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEILjAD#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=Quest for the Killers|last=Goodfield|first=June|date=August 1985|access-date=26 October 2017|publisher=Birkhauser|isbn=978-0-8176-3313-4|language=en}}</ref> who was paid 250 [[Bangladeshi taka|taka]].<ref name="PHIL7762">Image caption of U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control]] [http://phil.cdc.gov/phil/home.asp Public Health Image LibraryC image number 7762]</ref> Information on the case was forwarded via telegram to [[D.A. Henderson]], who led the [[World Health Organization]]'s campaign to eradicate the disease.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofvaccines.org/content/articles/smallpox | title = Interview with D.A. Henderson, sourced at History of Vaccines website | first=D.A. |last=Henderson | date=15 October 2010 | accessdate=15 October 2010| publisher=[[College of Physicians of Philadelphia]]}}</ref> The World Health Organization team arrived and cared for Banu, who recovered fully. On 24 November 1975 she was declared free of the virus.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t-DprF8lHcsC&q=%22Rahima+Banu%22&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIOTAF|title=The eradication of smallpox from Bangladesh|last=Joarder|first=A. Kashem|last2=Tarantola|first2=D.|last3=Tulloch|first3=J.|date=1 January 1980|publisher=World Health Organization, South-East Asia Regional Office|year=|isbn=9789290221081|location=|pages=48|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> Scabs of the virus from her body were transferred to the CDC office in Atlanta, where they are currently stored along with hundreds of other samples.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q_3CMS28mQQC&pg=PT73&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=Beating Back the Devil: On the Front Lines with the Disease Detectives of|last=McKenna|first=Maryn|date=17 June 2008|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781439104958|language=en}}</ref> Everyone on the island who might have come in contact with the infected were vaccinated, while the island was searched to find others who might still be infected.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=34ri3PIRaQEC&pg=PA91&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=The Demon in the Freezer|last=Preston|first=Richard|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Random House|year=|isbn=9780345466631|location=|pages=91|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> The strain from her sample is known as Bangladesh 1975 formally and the Rahima strain informally.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DnhqwXmB9cIC&pg=PA82&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIPzAG#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=The Best American Magazine Writing 2000|last=Felker|first=Clay|date=1 January 2000|publisher=PublicAffairs|year=|isbn=158648009X|location=|pages=82|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
== Later life == Banu created income for her family by posing for photos.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ECRnmrTVv9YC&pg=PA374&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIazAO#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=Smallpox: A History|last=Kotar|first=S. L.|last2=Gessler|first2=J. E.|date=12 April 2013|publisher=McFarland|year=|isbn=9780786468232|location=|pages=374|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> In an interview in 2009, Banu said she had four children after marrying a farmer at the age of 18. She said that villagers and her in-laws treated her poorly because she had suffered from smallpox.<ref>{{cite web|title=Asia Marks 30 Years since World Declared Free of Smallpox|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/a-13-2009-07-31-voa16-68743717/410219.html|work=[[Voice of America]]|accessdate=13 January 2014|date=2 November 2009}}</ref><ref name="PHIL7765">See also Image caption of U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] [http://phil.cdc.gov/phil/home.asp Public Health Image Library image number 7765]</ref>
== See also == * [[Ali Maow Maalin]], last person infected with naturally occurring ''Variola minor.''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v9RY2PVOtOMC&pg=PA45&dq=%22Rahima+Banu%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96YO2y-bQAhUriVQKHUpaD3YQ6AEIowEwFw#v=onepage&q=%22Rahima%20Banu%22&f=false|title=The Coming Plague: Newly Emerging Diseases in a World Out of Balance|last=Garrett|first=Laurie|date=31 October 1994|publisher=Macmillan|year=|isbn=9781429953276|location=|pages=45|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> * [[Janet Parker]], last known person to die from smallpox
==References== {{reflist}}

The '''Rebellion of Arbanon''' in 1257–1259 was a revolt of the [[Principality of Arbanon]] (in modern central [[Albania]]) against the [[Empire of Nicaea]] and in favour of the rival [[Despotate of Epirus]].
Arbanon had long been an autonomous principality within Epirus, and the Nicaean conquest around 1255 was resented. The rebellion was a reaction to the imposition of Nicaean rule in the person of governor [[Constantine Chabaron]]. The rebels were active in [[Durrë]], [[Ohrid]], [[Debar]] and [[Mat District|Mat]]. The Nicaean forces were under the command of [[George Akropolites]], who described the events himself in his history.
In the autumn of 1257, Akropolites left [[Thessaloniki]] and by way of [[Kastoria]] entered [[Kounavia]], Mat and Debar in an effort to convince the local chieftains to abandon the Despot of Epirus, [[Michael II of Epirus|Michael II]], and submit to imperial rule. Yet, in February 1258 the Nicaean garrisons were annihilated. Taking advantage of the situation, Michael II started his campaign against the Nicaeans and captured Chabaron in [[Kaninë Castle|Kanina]]. The Albanians drove back the imperial troops sent as reinforcements and Akropolites set fresh troops in the move, opening his way to Ohrid and Prespa, but without having a chance to engage the rebels in the inner regions. He was forced to return to [[Prilep]] and fell captive to Michael II. The revolt was suppressed after troops from Asia Minor were sent in the spring of 1259, headed by John Komnenos. The most decisive battle was fought in the city of [[Devol (Albania)|Devol]]. After suffering heavy losses, the Byzantines were finally able to control the situation, but in the years 1260–1270 the Albanian rulers revolted again in the region of [[Durrës]].<ref>Setton, Kenneth Meyer: The Papacy and the Levant, 1204–1571: The Thirteenth and fourteenth centuries, Volume 1. American Philosophical Society, 1976. page 74. [https://books.google.com/books?id=5Gm79HuBY0cC&pg=PA74]</ref><ref>George Akropolites: the history. Oxford University Press, 2007. Page 324. [https://books.google.com/books?id=fkKjkbBCjpkC&pg=PA320]</ref>

{{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Sonic Protest | image = | caption = | location = [[Paris]], [[France]] | years_active= 2003–present | founded by = | dates = April | website = [http://www.sonicprotest.com www.sonicprotest.com] }} '''Sonic Protest''' is a yearly [[music festival]] in [[France]] focused on left field music genres like [[experimental rock]], [[electroacoustic music]], [[improvised music]], [[noise music|noise]] and [[avant garde music]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Azoury Philippe|title=Sonic Protest toutes griffes dehors|url=http://www.liberation.fr/culture/0101101082-sonic-protest-toutes-griffes-dehors|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=[[Libération]]|date=3 May 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ariane Gruet-Pelchat|title=Festival Sonic Protest : tour d’horizon en vidéos|url=http://www.lesinrocks.com/2011/04/05/musique/festival-sonic-protest-tour-dhorizon-en-videos-1117287/|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=[[Les Inrockuptibles]]|date=5 April 2011}}</ref>
The first edition of Sonic Protest took place in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|last=Olivier Lamm|title=Sonic Protest nettoie vos oreilles|url=http://www.vogue.fr/culture/agenda/articles/festival-sonic-protest/7195|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|date=31 March 2011}}</ref> The editions from 2003 till 2011 took place in [[Paris]]. Acts like [[Deerhoof]], [[Shit & Shine]], [[Noël Akchoté]], [[Charles Hayward (musician)|Charles Hayward]], [[Keiji Haino]] and many others have performed at this festival.<ref>http://www.obskuremag.net/agenda/sonic-protest-2011-paris-du-02-au-10-avril-partenariat-festival/ Article on Obskure mag (in French)</ref> At the 2006<ref>http://www.discogs.com/Various-Sonic-Protest-2006/release/1576083</ref> and 2008 editions compilation cds with all the artists featured on the festival were released<ref>http://www.mimaroglumusicsales.com/labels/sonic+protest.html</ref> The 2012 edition was set up bigger than the predecessing editions and took place in five cities: [[Paris]], [[Reims]], [[Marseille]], [[Dijon]] and [[Tours]].<ref>http://www.noisemag.net/?p=11325 Article in Noise mag (in French)</ref> Local organisations such as [[GRIM]] in Marseille, supported the festival in the other cities.

[[Image:Spec7.jpg|thumb|300px|right|1982 Spec RX-7]] '''Spec RX-7''' is one of many production-based spec classes, originating in the mid-90's with the [[Sports Car Club of America]]. The class was created by Dave Turner and Mark Holland. The main fault of the class is a lack of nationwide compatibility, with each division having slightly different rulesets from one another. Some allow for vast modification, some allow very little, but they all are based on the premise of equality, with the skill being placed solely on the driver and reducing the need for costly development and "part of the week". Specs range from relatively stock including exhaust and intake, to mildly modified, to [[Improved Touring]] specs. All are based on the 79-85 year model [[RX-7]], with some excluding the 79-80 year models.
==Class rules== Since each division has a different set of specs, it is important to locate rules for your area. Below is a small listing of websites to help you locate these rules.
Most divisions (excluding the Improved Touring-based IT7 class) spec suspension, tires, engine modification, and in some cases rollcages and wheels.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = State Council of the USSR |nativename = Государственный Совет СССР |logo = State Emblem of the Soviet Union.svg |logo_caption = |formed = 5 September 1991 |preceding1 = [[Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union]] (as supreme government agency)
[[Soviet of the Federation]] (as coordinating government agency) |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |dissolved = 26 December 1991 |superseding = [[State Council of the Russian Federation]] |jurisdiction = [[Soviet Union|Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]] |headquarters = [[Moscow]], [[RSFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] |employees = |budget = }} Following the August [[1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt]], the '''State Council of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR)''' ({{lang-ru|Государственный Совет СССР}}), but also known as the '''State Soviet''', was formed on 5 September 1991 and was designed to be one of the most important government offices in [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s [[Soviet Union]]. The members of the council consisted of the [[President of the Soviet Union]], and [[Head of state|highest officials]] (which typically was [[president]]s of their republics) from the [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet Union Republics]]. During the period of transition it was the highest organ of state power, having the power to elect a [[List of Premiers of the Soviet Union|premier]], or a person who would take Gorbachev's place if absent; the office of [[Vice President of the Soviet Union]] had been abolished following the failed August Coup that very same year.{{Cite web| author= [[Government of the USSR]]: [[Mikhail Gorbachev|Gorbachev, Mikhail]] |script-title=ru:ЗАКОН СССР: Об органах государственной власти и управления Союза ССР в переходный период |trans-title=Law: About state governing bodies of USSR in a transition period On the bodies of state authority and administration of the USSR in Transition | url = http://www.sssr.su/zopp.html | accessdate=15 November 1991 |date=5 September 1991 |publisher=sssr.su|language=Russian}} ==Interstate Economic Committee== With the central government's authority greatly weakened by the failed coup, Gorbachev{{cite book | author = Garcelon, Marc | page = 167 | title = Revolutionary Passage: From Soviet to Post-Soviet Russia, 1985–2000 | location =Philadelphia | publisher = [[Temple University Press]] | year = 2005 | isbn = 1-59213-362-2}} established a four-man committee, led by Russian SFSR Premier [[Ivan Silayev]], that included [[Grigory Yavlinsky]], [[Arkadi Volsky]], and [[Yuri Luzhkov]], to elect a new [[Cabinet of Ministers (Soviet Union)|Cabinet of Ministers]]. This committee was later transformed into the '''Committee on the Operational Management of the Soviet Economy''' (COMSE), also chaired by Silayev, to manage the [[Soviet economy]].{{cite book | author = Jeffries, Ian | page = 100 | title = Socialist Economies and the Transition to the Market: A Guide | location =London; New York | publisher = [[Routledge]] | year = 1993 | isbn = 0-415-07580-7}} COMSE was quickly surpassed in authority by the '''Interstate Economic Committee of the Soviet Union''' ('''IEC'''), also officially known as the ''Economic Community'', which was established on 20 September under the name Inter-Republican Economic Committee. Its function was to coordinate economic policy across the Soviet Union. As Chairman of both COMSE and the IEC, Silayev presided over a quickly disintegrating Soviet Union.{{sfn|Shevchenko|2004|p=66}} On 6 September 1991 a [[presidential decree]] temporarily gave the IEC the same authority as the Cabinet of Ministers, and Silayev became the [[Premier of the Soviet Union|Soviet Union's ''de facto'' Premier]].{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.praviteli.org/ussr/ussr2/silayev.php | title = Silaev, Ivan Stepanovich | trans-title = Силаев, Иван Степанович | publisher = praviteli.org | accessdate = 4 April 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110507084311/http://www.praviteli.org/ussr/ussr2/silayev.php | archivedate = 7 May 2011 | df = }} When he first took office, Silayev wanted to reduce the powers of the central government and give more powers to the [[Republics of the Soviet Union|Soviet Republics]]. This view changed;{{sfn|Shevchenko|2004|p=66}} he demanded that Yeltsin give back much of the authority of the central government which he had usurped following the August Coup. In this he failed, and his position as Russian SFSR Premier was severely weakened as a result. Oleg Lobov, Silayev's [[First Deputy Premier of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|First Deputy Premier]], led the anti-Silayev faction in the Russian SFSR Council of Ministers and managed to oust him on 26 September 1991; Lobov succeeded Silayev as acting Premier of the Russian SFSR.{{sfn|Shevchenko|2004|p=66}} Silayev, as overseer of the economy, was given the task of initiating economic reforms in the Soviet Union in a way that suited both the central government and the Soviet republics.{{Cite book | author = Sakwa, Richard | title = Russian Politics and Society | location =London; New York | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-415-41527-6 | page = 33 | authorlink = Richard Sakwa }} Silayev tried to maintain an integrated economy while initiating the marketisation of the economy.{{Cite book | author = Sakwa, Richard | title = Russian Politics and Society | location =London;New York | publisher = [[Taylor & Francis]] | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-415-41527-6 | page = 228 | authorlink = Richard Sakwa }} The IEC showed its international intent by signing the [[European Energy Charter]] on 16/17 December 1991 with 35 other countries, but this was undermined by the charter also being signed by nine of the twelve remaining republics.[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/written_answers/1991/dec/19/european-energy-charter Hansard 19 December 1991 c242W] ==Dissolution of the Soviet Union== On 19 December COMSE was dissolved by a presidential decree, and Gorbachev resigned as Soviet President on 25 December. The next day, 26 December 1991, Silayev resigned from his post as IEC Chairman.{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | script-title=ru:Силаев, Иван Степанович |trans-title=Silayev, Ivan Stepanovich | language = Russian | publisher = warheroes.ru | url = http://www.warheroes.ru/hero/hero.asp?Hero_id=10962 | accessdate = 4 April 2010 | date = }} and the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union|Soviet Union was formally dissolved]] by the [[Soviet of Nationalities|Council of Republics]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Departments of the USSR|state=uncollapsed}} [[Category:Government of the Soviet Union|State Council]] [[Category:1991 disestablishments in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1991 establishments in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Perestroika]]

[[File:Chancel of Houston Memorial UMC on Good Friday.jpg|thumb|350px|On Maundy Thursday, the altar of this Methodist church was stripped and the crucifix of this Methodist church was veiled in black for Good Friday (black is the liturgical colour for Good Friday in the United Methodist Church). A wooden cross sits in front of the bare chancel for the veneration of the cross ceremony, which occurs during the United Methodist Good Friday liturgy.]] The '''Stripping of the Altar''' or the '''Stripping of the Chancel''' is a ceremony carried out in many [[Anglican]], [[Catholic]], [[Lutheran]] and [[Methodist]] churches on [[Maundy Thursday]].<ref>[http://www.elca.org/en/Living-Lutheran/Ask-a-Pastor/2013/10/~/link.aspx?_id=8A91118FE3E341839E13E7444A33CBF6&_z=z Living Lutheran, The Three Days: Traditions of Maundy Thursday, Good Friday and the Vigil of Easter].</ref>
At the end of the Maundy Thursday liturgy in Methodist parishes, the [[chancel]] is traditionally stripped; black [[parament]]s are sometimes added for [[Good Friday]] as black is the liturgical colour of Good Friday in the Methodist Churches.<ref name="Duck2013">{{cite book|last=Duck|first=Ruth C.|title=Worship for the Whole People of God: Vital Worship for the 21st Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VcQ7AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA131|accessdate=13 April 2014|year=2013|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|isbn=9780664234270|page=131|quote=The liturgical color is black-or no color if the paraments (altar cloths) have been stripped.}}</ref> Methodist custom holds that apart from depictions of the [[Stations of the Cross]], other images (such as the altar cross) continue the Lenten habitude of being veiled.<ref name="Hickman2011">{{cite book|last=Hickman|first=Hoyt L.|title=United Methodist Altars: A Guide for the Congregation (Revised Edition)|date=1 July 2011|publisher=Abingdon Press|isbn=9781426730696|page=55}}</ref>
In addition to the stripping of the altar at the conclusion of the Maundy Thursday liturgy in Lutheran Churches, the "lectern and pulpit are [also] left bare until Easter to symbolize the humiliation and barrenness of the cross."<ref name="Fakes1994">{{cite book|last=Fakes|first=Dennis R.|title=Exploring Our Lutheran Liturgy|year=1994|publisher=CSS Publishing|language=English|isbn=9781556735967|page=34}}</ref>
In Anglican Churches, this ceremony is also performed at the conclusion of Maundy Thursday services, "in which all appointments, linens, and paraments are removed from the altar and chancel in preparation for Good Friday."<ref name="CP2015">{{cite book|last=Publishing|first=Morehouse|title=The Episcopal Handbook, Revised Edition|year=2015|publisher=Church Publishing, Inc.|language=English |isbn=9780819229564|page=218|quote=stripping of the altar: Ceremony at the conclusion of the Maundy Thursday liturgy, in which all appointments, linens, and paraments are removed from the altar and chancel in preparation for Good Friday.}}</ref> [[File:Good Friday at St Andrew's - geograph.org.uk - 151729.jpg|thumb|left|250px|A stripped altar in an [[Anglican]] church on [[Good Friday]]]] In the earlier form of the [[Roman Rite]], the stripping of the altar was done at the end of [[Mass of the Lord's Supper]] on [[Maundy Thursday]]. It is still carried out All altars in the church, except for the [[altar of repose]], are stripped. In the present form of the Roman Rite, as revised in 1955, there is no ceremony of stripping the altar. At a suitable time after the Mass the altar is stripped, usually by the [[sacristan]], and crosses are removed from the church, if possible.<ref>[[Roman Missal]]. Thursday of the Lord's Supper, 41.</ref> There is no Mass on [[Good Friday]] or [[Holy Saturday]], the next one being that of the [[Easter Vigil]]. On Good Friday, a white cloth is placed on the altar for the last part of the Celebration of the Passion of the Lord,<ref>[[Roman Missal]]. Friday of the Passion of the Lord (Good Friday), 22.</ref> after the conclusion of which the altar is stripped, again privately, except that the [[Christian cross|cross]] remains on the altar with two or four candlesticks.<ref>[[Roman Missal]], Friday of the Passion of the Lord (Good Friday), 33.</ref>
The form of the Roman Rite in use immediately before the reform of the [[Easter Triduum]] ceremonies by [[Pope Pius XII]] in 1955 had a formal ceremony of stripping the altar as a conclusion of the Holy Thursday Mass, which was then celebrated in the morning. After removing the [[ciborium (container)|ciborium]] from the [[high altar]] to the altar of repose, the priest, accompanied by the other ministers, went to the [[sacristy]], where he took off his white Mass vestments and donned a violet [[stole (vestment)|stole]]. Then, with the other ministers, he removed the altarcloths, vases of flowers, [[antependium]] and all other ornaments then customarily placed on the altar. Unlike present usage, the [[altar cross]] and candlesticks were left on the altar. This was done to the accompaniment of [[Psalm 22|Psalm 21 (Vulgate)]] (''[[Deus, Deus meus]]'') preceded and followed by the [[antiphon]] "Diviserunt sibi vestimenta mea: et super vestem meam miserunt sortem" ("They divided my clothes among them and cast lots for my garment").<ref name=Schulte>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Stripping of an Altar}}.</ref>
In earlier centuries, the altars were in some churches washed with a bunch of [[hyssop]] dipped in wine and water. [[Augustine Schulte|Augustine Joseph Schulte]] says that this was done "to render them in some manner worthy of the Lamb without stain who is immolated on them, and to recall to the minds of the faithful with how great purity they should assist at the Holy Sacrifice and receive Holy Communion." He adds that the ceremony was intended as homage offered to Jesus in return for his humbly washing the feet of his disciples,<ref name=Schulte/> the ceremonial commemoration of which was, before 1955, carried out separately from the Mass and stripping of the altar.
[[Eamonn Duffy]] alludes to this ceremony in his book ''[[The Stripping of the Altars|The Stripping of the Altars: Traditional Religion in England, 1400–1580]]'', a history of popular religion in pre-[[Reformation]] England.

{{for|the dancer and choreographer|Sushmita Banerjee (dancer)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox writer | image = SushmitaBanerjeePic.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1963/1964 | birth_place = [[Calcutta, India]] (present-day [[Kolkata, India]]) | death_date = 4/5 September 2013 (aged 49) | death_place = [[Paktika Province|Paktika Province, Afghanistan]] | notableworks = ''Kabuliwalar Bangali Bou''
(''A Kabuliwala's Bengali Wife'') | spouse = Janbaz Khan | religion = Hindu, then Islam}} '''Sushmita Banerjee''', also known as '''Sushmita Bandhopadhyay''' and '''Sayeda Kamala'''{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Indian-author-Sushmita-Banerjee-executed-in-Afghanistan-by-Taliban/articleshow/22349517.cms|title=Indian author Sushmita Banerjee executed in Afghanistan by Taliban|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=5 September 2013}} (1963/1964 – 4/5 September 2013), was a writer and activist from India. Her works include the memoir ''Kabuliwalar Bangali Bou'' (''A Kabuliwala's Bengali Wife''; 1997) based on her experience of marrying an [[Afghan people|Afghan]] and her time in Afghanistan during [[Taliban]] rule. The story was used as the basis for the [[Bollywood]] film ''[[Escape from Taliban]]''. At the age of 49, she was killed by suspected Taliban militants during the evening of 4 September or in the early morning hours of 5 September 2013, outside her home in [[Paktika Province|Paktika Province, Afghanistan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/09/05/world/asia/afghanistan-indian-author-killed/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|title=Afghan militants target, kill female author, police say| last1= Narayan|first1=Chandrika|last2=Popalzai|first2=Masoud|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=5 September 2013| accessdate=5 September 2013}} ==Life== Sushmita Banerjee was born in [[Kolkata|Calcutta]] [[West Bengal]] (present-day [[Kolkata, India]]) to a middle-class [[Bengali Brahmin]] family. Her father worked in the civil defence department and her mother, a homemaker. She was the only sister to her three brothers. She first met her future husband Janbaz Khan, an Afghan businessman, at a theatre rehearsal in Calcutta.{{Cite newspaper |title=Indian diarist Sushmita Banerjee 'had no fear'|journal=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-23984518|date=6 September 2013|accessdate=7 September 2013|last1=Biswas|first1=Soutik}} She married him on 2 July 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/interview/exclusive-just-who-is-susmita-banerjee/20130905.htm|title=Exclusive: Knowing Sushmita Banerjee|date=5 September 2013|accessdate=5 September 2013| publisher=[[Rediff.com]]}} The marriage took place secretly in Kolkata, as she feared her parents would object to the inter-religious marriage. When her parents tried to get them divorced, she fled to Afghanistan with Khan. She discovered that her husband already had a first wife, Gulguti, when she found them in bed together. Although shocked, she continued to live in Khan's ancestral house in Patiya village, with her three brothers-in-law, their wives, and with Gulguti and Gulguti's children. Later, Khan returned to Kolkata to continue his business, but Banerjee could not return. Sayeda, a trained nurse in [[gynaecology]], opened a clinic to help the women of the village. With the burgeoning Taliban power in Afghanistan, Banerjee witnessed fundamentalist changes occurring in the country. In a 2003 interview, she said that the plight of women in particular got worse. Women were banned from talking with men other than family members, they were not allowed outside home. Schools, colleges, and hospitals were shut down. Taliban men discovered her clinic and beat her severely in May 1995. Banerjee made two abortive attempts to flee Afghanistan. She was caught and kept in house arrest in the village. A [[fatwa]] was issued against her and she was scheduled to die on 22 July 1995. With the help of the village headman, she finally fled from the village, in the process killing three Taliban men with an [[AK-47]] rifle. She reached Kabul, and took a flight back to Kolkata on 12 August 1995. She lived in India until 2013, and published several books. After returning to Afghanistan, she worked as a health worker in [[Paktika Province]] in southeastern Afghanistan, and began filming the lives of local women. ==Death== According to Afghan police, suspected Taliban terrorists forced entry into her house in Paktika on the night of 4 September 2013. They bound her husband and absconded with her. Her corpse was found early the next day beside a ''[[madrasa]]'' in the outskirts of the provincial capital [[Sharana, Afghanistan|Sharana]]. The body had 20 bullet hole marks. Police surmised she might have been targeted for murder for various reasons, including her book, her social work in the region, or merely the fact that she was an Indian woman, or according to others for not wearing a [[burqa]], for which she was sentenced to death almost two decades earlier, under the Taliban regime.{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/south-asia/sushmita-banerjee-was-shot-25-times-taliban-deny-responsibility_874583.html|title=Sushmita Banerjee was killed for not wearing burqa?|work=Zee News|date=2013-09-06}} The Taliban denied involvement in this attack.{{cite news|title=Indian diarist Sushmita Banerjee shot dead in Afghanistan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-23968427|newspaper=BBC News|date=5 September 2013}} Later a spokesman for renegade Taliban militia known as The Suicide Group of the Islamic Movement of Afghanistan announced it had killed Banerjee. The group, led by Mullah Najibullah, explained that they had kidnapped, interrogated and then murdered Banerjee because they believed she was "an Indian spy". Although some of her neighbours reflected that her death may have been partly caused by her not following local Afghan traditions, especially regarding the wearing of a burqa outside the home.Yousafzai, Sami and Moreau, Ron (14 September 2013) [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/09/14/we-killed-sushmita-banerjee-says-renegade-taliban-militia.html ‘We Killed Sushmita Banerjee’ Says Renegade Taliban Militia] thedailybeast.com ==Books== Sushmita Banerjee wrote ''Kabuliwalar Bangali Bou'' ("A Kabuliwala's Bengali Wife") in 1995. It recounted the tale of her love marriage to an Afghan businessman, Jaanbaz Khan, her moving to Afghanistan in 1989, the adversities she faced in Talibani Afghanistan, and her eventual escape back to Kolkata. In 2003, ''[[Escape from Taliban]]'', a [[Bollywood]] film, starring Manisha Koirala was made based on the book. She authored ''Talibani Atyachar—Deshe o Bideshe'' (Taliban atrocities in Afghanistan and Abroad), ''Mullah Omar, Taliban O Ami'' (Mullah Omar, Taliban and I) (2000), ''Ek Borno Mithya Noi'' (''Not a Word is a Lie'') (2001) and ''Sabhyatar Sesh Punyabani'' (The Swansong of Civilisation).{{cite news|last=Mitra|first=Sumit|title=On hostile tract : Tales of Taliban barbarism by Afghan's Bengali wife become a bestseller, being filmed|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/tales-of-taliban-barbarism-by-afghans-bengali-wife-become-a-bestseller-being-filmed/1/231484.html|newspaper=India Today|date=22 October 2001}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2002-05-15/kolkata/27135718_1_omar-s-taliban-taliban-leader-mullah-omar|title=Kabuliwala's wife turns director|newspaper=The Times of India|date=15 May 2002|accessdate=5 September 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://news.biharprabha.com/2013/09/the-biography-of-slain-writer-sushmita-banerjee Biography of Sushmita Banerjee] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Banejee, Sushmita}} [[Category:1960s births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Bengali writers]] [[Category:Bengali-language writers]] [[Category:Writers from Kolkata]] [[Category:Indian women's rights activists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women writers]] [[Category:20th-century Indian writers]] [[Category:People murdered in Afghanistan]] [[Category:People killed by the Taliban]] [[Category:Indian expatriates in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Violence against women in Afghanistan]] [[Category:People from Paktika Province]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]] [[Category:Manslaughter victims]] [[Category:Women writers from West Bengal]] [[Category:Indian women activists]]

{{italic title}} '''''The Conclave''''' is a 2006 Canadian/German film production directed by [[Christoph Schrewe]]. The script was written by [[Paul Donovan (writer)|Paul Donovan]].
==Plot==
The plot centers on the [[Papal conclave, 1458|conclave of 1458]], which took place five years after the [[fall of Constantinople]] to the [[Ottoman Empire|Turks]]. The story material was sourced from a diary written by Silvius Aeneas Piccolomini, the only cardinal to ever record the secret proceedings of a papal conclave. The Conclave hinges on the drama surrounding a 27-year-old Spaniard, Cardinal Rodrigo Borgia (later [[Pope Alexander VI]]) as he struggles to save both his career and his life.
==Cast== {{Cast listing| *[[Manuel Fullola]] as ''[[Pope Alexander VI|Rodrigo Borgia]]'' *[[Brian Blessed]] as ''[[Pope Pius II|Aeneas Sylvius Piccolomini]]'' *[[James Faulkner (actor)|James Faulkner]] as ''[[Guillaume d'Estouteville]]'' *[[Rolf Kanies]] as ''[[Basilios Bessarion]]'' *[[Holger Kunkel]] as ''[[Alain de Coëtivy]]'' *[[Peter Guinness (actor)|Peter Guinness]] as ''[[Latino Orsini]]'' *[[Nicholas Irons]] as ''[[Prospero Colonna (cardinal)|Prospero Colonna]]'' *[[Brian Downey (actor)|Brian Downey]] as ''[[Juan de Mella]]'' *[[Lolo Herrero]] as ''[[Pedro Luis de Borja|Pedro Luis Borgia]]'' *[[Gaetano Carotenuto]] as ''Captain Gaetono'' *[[Matthias Koeberlin]] as ''[[Giuliano Della Rovere]]'' *[[Nora Tschirner]] as ''[[Vannozza dei Cattanei]]'' *[[Joseph Rutten]] as ''[[Pope Callixtus III]]'' *[[John Dunsworth]] as ''[[Filippo Calandrini]]'' }}

{{Good article}} {{Infobox Hurricane | Name=Typhoon June (Maring) | Type=typhoon | Year=1984 | Basin=WPac | Image location=June Aug 29 1984 0727Z.png | Image name=June on August 29 at 07:27 UTC | Formed={{start date|August 26, 1984}} | Dissipated={{end date|September 1, 1984}} | 1-min winds=60 | 10-min winds=65 | Pressure=985 | Fatalities=121 total, 17 missing | Damages=24.2 | Areas={{flatlist| * [[Philippines]] * [[China]] }} | Hurricane season=[[1984 Pacific typhoon season]] }} '''Typhoon June''', also known in the Philippines as '''Typhoon Maring''', was the first of two [[tropical cyclone]]s to affect the Philippines in a one-week time span in August 1984. June originated from an area of [[atmospheric convection|convection]] that was first witnessed on August 15 in the [[Philippine Sea]]. Despite initial [[wind shear]], the area intensified into a tropical storm three days later as it tracked westward. After tracking over Luzon, June entered the [[South China Sea]] on August 30. Despite remaining poorly organized, June re-intensified over land, and it was estimated to have briefly attained typhoon intensity before striking China, just to the east of [[Hong Kong]], at maximum intensity, although its remnants were last noticed on September 3.
Affecting the country four days before [[Typhoon Ike]] would devastate the Philippines, June brought widespread damage to the nation. Throughout the Philippines, 470,962 people sought shelter. A total of 671 homes were destroyed, with 6,341 others damaged. A total of 121 people were killed, while 17 other individuals were reportedly missing, and 26 other people were wounded. Damage totaled $24.2 million (1984 [[United States Dollars|USD]], including $15.24 million in agriculture and $8.82 million in infrastructure). Following June and Ike, several major countries provided cash and other goods. In all, $7.5 million worth of aid was donated to the nation in relief. In addition to effects on the Philippines, 1,500 homes were damaged and {{convert|66,000|ha|acre|abbr=on}} of farmland were flooded in the [[Guangdong]] province.
== Meteorological history == {{storm path|June 1984 track.png}} Typhoon June, the final of seven [[tropical cyclones]] to develop in the [[tropical cyclone basins|Western Pacific basin]] in August 1984, formed from the [[monsoon trough]]. A large area of convection was first detected on [[satellite imagery]], and at midday, the [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] determined that a [[low pressure area|closed area of low pressure]] developed between the [[135th meridian east]] and the [[140th meridian east]]. The associated thunderstorm activity initially failed to consolidate due to strong [[wind shear]] caused by a displaced [[anticyclone]].<ref name="JTWC ATCR">{{cite report|title=Annual Tropical Cyclone Report: 1984|publisher=United States Navy, United States Air Force|url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/atcr/1984atcr.pdf|author2=Naval Pacific Meteorology and Oceanography Center|author=Joint Typhoon Warning Center|accessdate=May 24, 2017|year=1987|format=[[PDF]]}}</ref> The [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] (JMA) started to track the system 06:00 UTC on August 26.<ref name="JMA">{{cite report|author=Japan Meteorological Agency|date=October 10, 1992|title=RSMC Best Track Data – 1980–1989|accessdate=May 24, 2017|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/jma-eng/jma-center/rsmc-hp-pub-eg/Besttracks/bst8089.txt|format=[[.TXT]]}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|The [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] is the official [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Center]] for the western Pacific Ocean.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency|title=Annual Report on Activities of the RSMC Tokyo – Typhoon Center 2000|date=February 2001|accessdate=May 24, 2017|url=http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/jma-eng/jma-center/rsmc-hp-pub-eg/AnnualReport/2000/Text/Text2000.pdf|page=3|format=PDF}}</ref>|group="nb"}} The next day, the wind shear began to relent, as an upper-level anticyclone became located over the system as the system tracked westward, although the [[atmospheric circulation|circulation]] remained tough to identify by [[weather satellite]]s. At 06:51 UTC on August 27, a [[Hurricane Hunter]] aircraft reported winds of {{convert|35|mph|km/h|order=flip|abbr=on|round=5}}. Based on the above data and an increase in the system's organization, the JTWC issued a [[Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert]]. On August 28, the storm's center of circulation became better defined,<ref name="JTWC ATCR" /> and at 06:00 UTC, both the JTWC and JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm.<ref name="IBTRACS">{{cite report|author1=Kenneth R. Knapp |author2=Michael C. Kruk |author3=David H. Levinson |author4=Howard J. Diamond |author5=Charles J. Neumann |year=2010|work=The International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS): Unifying tropical cyclone best track data|title=1984 June (1984238N18137)|publisher=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|accessdate=May 24, 2017|url=http://www.atms.unca.edu/ibtracs/ibtracs_current/browse-ibtracs/index.php?name=v03r09-1984238N18137}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|Wind estimates from the JMA and most other basins throughout the world are [[maximum sustained winds|sustained]] over 10 minutes, while estimates from the United States-based Joint Typhoon Warning Center are sustained over 1 minute. 10‑minute winds are about 1.14 times the amount of 1‑minute winds.<ref name="FAQD4">{{cite book|author=Christopher W Landsea|author2=Hurricane Research Division|title=Frequently Asked Questions:|chapter=Subject: D4) What does "maximum sustained wind" mean? How does it relate to gusts in tropical cyclones?|accessdate=May 24, 2017|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/E7.html|date=April 26, 2004}}</ref>|group="nb"}} Around this time, the [[Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration]] (PAGASA) also began to monitor the storm and [[List of historical tropical cyclone names|assigned it with the local name]] ''Maring''.<ref name="T2000">{{cite report|url=http://www.typhoon2000.ph/stormstats/1963-1988_PTC.txt|title=PAGASA Tropical Cyclone Names 1963–1988|first1=Michael V.|format=TXT|last1=Padua|publisher=Typhoon 2000|accessdate=May 24, 2017|date=November 6, 2008}}</ref>
Continuing westward due to a [[subtropical ridge]] to its north,<ref name="JTWC ATCR" /> June slowly intensified.<ref name="BT">{{cite report|url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/best_tracks/1984/1984s-bwp/bwp141984.txt|title=Tropical Storm 14W Best Track|date=December 17, 2002|publisher=Joint Typhoon Warning Center|accessdate=May 24, 2017|format=TXT}}</ref> On the afternoon of August 28, June made [[landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] along the coast of [[Luzon]]<ref name="JTWC ATCR" /> as a strong tropical storm, with the JTWC and JMA estimating winds of {{convert|65|mph|km/h|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}} and {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}} respectively.<ref name="IBTRACS" /> Over land, the low- and mid-level circulations began to decouple, with the mid-level center and most of the deep convection continuing west and the low-level center veering west-northwest and early on August 29, the surface center re-merged into open water,<ref name="JTWC ATCR" /> having weakened slightly according to both the JTWC and the JMA.<ref name="IBTRACS" /> June began to turn northwest in response to a [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] over the [[East China Sea]].<ref name="JTWC ATCR" /> At 18:00 UTC on August 29, the JMA classified June as a [[tropical cyclone scales|severe tropical storm]].<ref name="JMA" /> Six hours later, the JTWC reported that June attained its peak intensity of {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}}.<ref name="BT" /> Despite lacking in organization,<ref name="BT" /> a surface pressure of {{convert|986|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}} was measured in [[Basco, Batanes|Basco]] as the cyclone passed near the area.<ref name="HKO">{{cite report|author1=[[Hong Kong Observatory]]|title=Meteorological Results: 1984|chapter=Part III – Tropical Cyclone Summaries|journal=Meteorological Results|year=1985|url=http://www.hko.gov.hk/publica/tc/tc1984.pdf|accessdate=May 25, 2017|pages=26–29|publisher=Hong Kong Observatory|format=PDF}}</ref> The JMA declared June a typhoon at midday on August 30. At this time, it also estimated a peak intensity of {{convert|75|mph|km/h|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}} and a minimum [[barometric pressure]] of {{convert|985|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}}.<ref name="JMA" /> Five hours later, June made landfall {{convert|240|km|mi|abbr=on}} east of [[Hong Kong]]<ref name="JTWC ATCR" /> while at peak intensity.<ref name="IBTRACS" /> The JMA continued to follow the system inland throughout September 3.<ref name="JMA" />
== Impact == Typhoon June hit the Philippines four days before [[Typhoon Ike]] would devastate the archipelago.<ref name="UPI1" /> The first storm to hit the Philippines in 1984, June brought rough seas from [[Luzon]] to [[Davao Region|Davao]]. [[Philippine Airlines]] suspended flights to eight cities and railway services to the northern portions of the island chain were also suspended.<ref name="UPI2">{{cite news|title=Tropical storm kills 7, injures 127|agency=United Press International|date=August 29, 1984}} {{subscription required|via=Lexis Nexis}}</ref> Power was knocked out for four days across much of the country due to both systems.<ref name="UPI1" /> Six people were killed in landslides that isolated the mountain resort city of [[Baguio]], where five others were missing and seven were injured. According to the [[Philippine News Agency]], a 22-year-old man picking seashells drowned after he was swept out to sea near [[Bacolod]], on [[Negros (Philippines)|Negros Island]]. In [[San Fernando, La Union|San Fernando]], located in the northern province of [[La Union]], 200 houses were flattened and 120 people were injured. In [[Manila]], heavy winds and rough seas left streets flooded, resulting in traffic jams.<ref name="UPI2" /> The storm caused serious damage to the nation's rice fields, the country's main export.<ref name="UPI1" />
From the two storms combined, more than 1 million were displaced from their homes.<ref name="UPI1">{{cite news|title=Typhoon death toll rises to 438, may go higher|agency=United Press International|date=September 4, 1984}} {{subscription required|via=Lexis Nexis}}</ref> Throughout the Philippines, 470,962 people or 92,271 families sought shelter due to the typhoon,<ref name="NDCC2" /> of which 5,023 families or 30,138 people sought shelter in schools, churches and town halls in a total of 10 provinces.<ref name="UPI2" /> A total of 671 homes were destroyed while 6,341 others were damaged. One hundred-twenty-one people were killed while 17 other individuals were reportedly missing and 26 other people were wounded.<ref name="NDCC2">{{cite report|url=http://baseportal.com/cgi-bin/baseportal.pl?htx=/miso/typhoons&range=80,20|title=Destructive Typhoons 1970–2003|date=November 9, 2004|publisher=National Disaster Coordinating Council|accessdate=May 25, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041109181317/http://baseportal.com/cgi-bin/baseportal.pl?htx=%2Fmiso%2Ftyphoons&range=80%2C20|archivedate=November 9, 2004|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> The storm inflicted $24.2 million in damage, with $15.2 million in agriculture and $8.82 million in infrastructure.<ref name="NDCC">{{cite report|url=http://baseportal.com/cgi-bin/baseportal.pl?htx=/miso/typhoons&cmd=list&range=80,20&cmd=all&Id=86|title=Destructive Typhoons 1970–2003|date=November 9, 2004|publisher=National Disaster Coordinating Council|accessdate=May 25, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041126011214/http://baseportal.com/cgi-bin/baseportal.pl?htx=%2Fmiso%2Ftyphoons&cmd=list&range=80%2C20&cmd=all&Id=86|archivedate=November 26, 2004|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|All Philippine currencies are converted to United States Dollars using [http://www.measuringworth.com/datasets/exchangeglobal/result.php?year_source=1984&year_result=1984&countryE Philippines Measuring worth] with an exchange rate of the year 1984.|group=nb}}
Prior to its second landfall, in Hong Kong, a [[Hong Kong tropical cyclone warning signals|No 1. hurricane signal]] was issued after June entered the South China Sea. The storm brought heavy rains and strong winds to the region. A minimum pressure of {{convert|990|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}} was recorded at the [[Hong Kong Royal Observatory]] early on August 30. [[Tate's Cairn]] recorded a peak wind speed of {{convert|50|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} and a peak wind gust of {{convert|78|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. [[Cheung Chau]] observed {{convert|187.3|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain over a five-day period. Although damage in Hong Kong was minimal, heavy rains in eastern [[Guangdong]] inundated {{convert|66,000|ha|acre|abbr=on|round=5}} of farmland, and damage to 1,500 dwellings.<ref name="HKO" />
== Aftermath ==
Due to effects from both Ike and June, President [[Ferdinand Marcos]] set aside $4 million for relief work but initially refused any international aid.<ref>{{cite news|agency=British Broadcasting Company|date=September 3, 2009|accessdate=May 25, 2017|title=On This Day: September 3|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/september/3/newsid_2496000/2496059.stm}}</ref> He also traveled to [[Ilocos Norte]] to inspect damage.<ref>{{cite news|title=International News|agency=United Press International|date=September 6, 1984}}</ref> The [[Philippines Air Force]] delivered {{convert|2,000,000|lbs|kg|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}} of food, medicine, and clothes.<ref name="IAP15">{{cite news|title=Marcos Ventures Into Rebel Area That Was Ravaged by Typhoon|agency=Associated Press|date=September 9, 1984}} {{subscription required|via=Lexis Nexis}}</ref> According to officials, 92 health teams backed by 17 army medical units were fielded; these teams distributed $1.66 million worth of medicine.<ref name="IUPI10">{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Jack|title=Typhoon death toll tops 1,360 in Philippines|agency=United Press International|date=September 6, 1984}} {{subscription required|via=Lexis Nexis}}</ref> The [[Philippine Red Cross]] disturbed food to 239,331 people, or 44,247 families.<ref name="RW">{{cite report|title=Philippines Typhoons Sep 1984 UNDRO Situation Reports 1 – 7|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/philippines/philippines-typhoons-sep-1984-undro-situation-reports-1-7|accessdate=May 25, 2017|publisher=Relief Web|date=September 13, 1984}}</ref> On September 8, the nation abandoned its policy of refusing foreign aid, citing a lack of resources in the country due to its poor economy, as well as, the mass destruction across the country from both systems.<ref name="UPI14">{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=Jack|title=International News|agency=United Press International|date=September 8, 1984}}</ref> The [[United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] gave an emergency grant of $50,000. [[UNICEF]] provided $116,000 worth of vitamins and medicine and an additional $116,950 in cash, as well as {{convert|28|ST|MT|abbr=on}} of milk powder. Thy later provided vegetable seeds, died fish, and garden fertilizer. The [[World Health Organization]] provided $7,000 worth of aid. Furthermore, the [[United Nations Development Programme]] awarded the country $30,000 in cash. The [[European Economic Community]] provided {{convert|300|ST|MT|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}} of milk and $367,650 worth of cash.<ref name="RW" /> In the middle of September, the United States approved $1 million in aid to the archipelago. [[Japan]] also sent a $500,000 check.<ref name="IUPI21">{{cite news|title=Foreign News Beliefs|agency=United Press International|date=September 14, 1984}} {{subscription required|via=Lexis Nexis}}</ref> [[Australia]] awarded almost $500,000 worth of cash and food. [[New Zealand]] donated {{convert|50,000|lbs|kg|abbr=on|round=5|order=flip}} of skin milk. The [[Norwegian Red Cross]] provided $58,500 in aid while [[Belgium]] also provided three medical kits. The [[Swiss Red Cross]] awarded a little under $21,000 in cash. [[Germany|German]] provided slightly more than $50,000 in cash. [[France]] provided roughly $11,000 in donations to the nation's red cross. The [[Red Cross Society of China]] donated $20,000 in cash. [[Indonesia]] provided $25,000 worth of medicine. The [[United Kingdom]] granted $74,441 in aid. Overall, [[Relief Web]] reported that over $7.5 million was donated to the Philippines due to the storm.<ref name="RW" />
== See also == {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} * [[Typhoon Mike]] – Passed north of Mindanao and impacted the central Philippines, resulting in catastrophic damage * [[Typhoon Nelson (1982)]] – Resulted in significant flooding across the Philippines after slowly traversing the archipelago * [[Typhoon Lynn (1987)]] * [[Tropical Storm Kelly]] * [[Typhoon Agnes (1984)|Typhoon Agnes (1984)]] – Caused extensive damage and fatalities in the central Philippines before striking Vietnam

{{Infobox company | name = Vignette Corporation | logo = Vignette.png | industry = [[Software]] | fate = Acquired by [[Open Text Corporation]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1995}} | founder = Ross Garber
Neil Webber | defunct = {{end date and age|2009|07|21}} | location = [[Austin, Texas]] }} '''Vignette Corporation''' offered a suite of [[content management]], [[web portal]], [[collaboration]], [[document management]], and [[records management]] software. Targeted at the enterprise market, Vignette offered products under the name [[StoryServer]] that allowed non-technical users to create, edit and track content through workflows and publish it on the web. It provided integration for [[enterprise resource planning]], [[customer relationship management]] and legacy systems, supporting [[Java EE]] and [[Microsoft.NET]]. Vignette's [[integrated development environment]] and [[application programming interface]] offered an alternative to conventional [[Common Gateway Interface]]/[[vi]]/[[Perl]] web development. StoryServer was used on many large websites including those of [[CNET]], [[UnitedHealth Group]], [[The Walt Disney Company]], [[Wachovia]], [[Martha Stewart]], [[Fox News]], [[National Geographic (U.S. TV channel)|National Geographic Channel]], [[MetLife]], [[BSkyB]], the [[2004 Summer Olympics]], and [[NASA]].{{cite news | url=https://www.cio.com/article/2436135/enterprise-architecture/nasa-phoenix-mission-to-mars--an-out-of-this-world-content-management-challe.html | title=NASA Phoenix Mission to Mars: An Out-Of-This-World Content Management Challenge | first=Laurianne | last=McLaughlin | work=[[CIO magazine]] | date=May 22, 2008}} Its V6 content suites was priced at $200,000-$400,000.{{cite news | url=http://au.pcmag.com/internet-products/8479/review/vignette-v6-content-suite | title=Vignette V6 Content Suite | first=John | last=Clyman | work=[[PC Magazine]] | date=February 23, 2007}} In 2009, the company was acquired by [[Open Text Corporation]]. ==History== In November 1995, Ross Garber and Neil Webber founded the company with the goal of making web publishing easier and more personalized.{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2000-06-04/making-the-web-go | title=Making The Web Go | first=Spencer E. | last=Ante | work=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] | date=June 5, 2000}}{{subscription required}}{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2002/08/05/story2.html | title=Big vision for Vignette | first=Stacey | last=Higginbotham | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=August 4, 2002}} In 1996, the company developed StoryBuilder, its first product, which handled large-scale content management workflow. During the initial development, Vignette partnered with [[CNET]], which had developed its own technology called PRISM that allowed for the creation and delivery of large, database-driven websites. CNET transferred the technology and $500,000 in cash to Vignette for a 33% stake in the company.{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/1998/10/14/side1.html | title=Vignette is the story | first=Om | last=Malik | authorlink=Om Malik | work=[[Forbes]] | date=October 14, 1998}}{{cite news | url=https://www.cnet.com/news/vignette-produces-web-site-tools/ | title=Vignette produces Web site tools | work=[[CNET]] | date=November 13, 1996}}{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/1996/09/16/story7.html | title=CNET ups its Vignette stake | first=Neil | last=Orman | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=September 15, 1996}} In February 1996, the company received $400,000 of [[seed money]] from [[Austin Ventures]] and Sigma Partners. In July 1996, the company raised $3 million. In January 1997, the company released [[StoryServer]], developed from technology acquired from CNET. It was updated in September 1997.{{cite news | url=https://www.cnet.com/news/vignette-updates-storyserver-platform/ | title=Vignette updates StoryServer platform | first=PAUL | last=FESTA | work=[[CNET]] | date=September 16, 1997}} In January 1998, Vignette and [[Firefly (website)|Firefly Networks]] proposed the XML based [[Information and Content Exchange]] (ICE) protocol for content syndication and submitted the specification to the [[World Wide Web Consortium]] standards body on October 26, 1998.{{cite news | url=https://www.xml.com/pub/a/ws/SeyboldReport/ip020701.html | title=Vignette and Firefly propose the ICE protocol | first=Victor | last=Votsch | work=XML.com | date=March 10, 1998}}{{cite web | url=https://www.w3.org/TR/1998/NOTE-ice-19981026 | title=The Information and Content Exchange (ICE) Protocol | publisher=W3 | date=October 26, 1998}} In May 1998, the company acquired RandomNoise.{{cite news | url=https://www.cnet.com/news/vignette-to-buy-randomnoise/ | title=Vignette to buy RandomNoise | work=[[CNET]] | date=May 11, 1998}} In June 1998, Garber hired [[Greg Peters (businessman)|Greg Peters]] to succeed him as CEO, and Garber became chairman of the board.{{cite news | url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/1999/1129/6413220a.html | title=Automating the Web | first=Daniel | last=Fisher | work=[[Forbes]] | date=November 29, 1999}} In July 1998, the company launched StoryServer 4, which featured strong support of [[XML]] technology. By December 1998, the company raised an additional $27.5 in [[venture capital]]. The number of the company's customers rose from 130 in 1998 to 700 in 2000. On February 19, 1999, during the [[dot-com bubble]], the company became a [[public company]] via an [[initial public offering]]. On the first day of trading, the stock price rose 152%, from $19 to $47.{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/1999/02/19/technology/webtrends/ | title=Internet IPOs soar | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=February 19, 1999}} On February 22, 1999, the company release Vignette Syndication Server. After the IPO, in 1999, Garber, worth $200 million at the age of 33, sold most of his stock and left the company.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/20/magazine/austin-we-have-a-problem.html | title=Austin, We Have a Problem | first=HELEN | last=THORPE | work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] | date=August 20, 2000}} In May 1999, the company acquired Diffusion for 400,000 shares of its stock, then worth $32.9 million.{{cite news | url=http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/114441/Vignette+Acquires+Diffusion.htm | title=Vignette Acquires Diffusion | first=Cyrus | last=Afzali | work=[[QuinStreet]] | date=May 11, 1999}} In January 2000, the company acquired [[DataSage]], a data mining and personalization application vendor, for $606 million.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB947537057569483479 | title=Vignette Sets Deal to Buy DataSage For $606.4 Million, Lifting Shares | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=January 11, 2000}}{{subscription required}}{{cite news | url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/737648/Vignette-to-acquire-DataSage-for-5536M-in-stock.html | title=Vignette to acquire DataSage for $553.6M in stock | agency=[[Bloomberg News]] | publisher=[[Deseret News]] | date=January 10, 2000}}{{cite news | url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/2594251/vignette-buys-datasage-for--595-million.html | title=Vignette buys DataSage for $595 million | first=Robin A. | last=Robinson | work=[[Computerworld]] | date=January 10, 2000}} In May 2000, the company acquired OnDisplay, an e-business application vendor, for $1.4 billion.{{cite news | url=http://www.internetnews.com/ec-news/article.php/376561/Vignette+Acquires+OnDisplay+for+17+Billion.htm | title=Vignette Acquires OnDisplay for $1.7 Billion | first=Thor | last=Olavsrud | work=[[QuinStreet]] | date=May 22, 2000}}{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB958998993581419539 | title=Vignette to Buy OnDisplay For $1.28 Billion in Stock | first=Gary | last=McWilliams | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=May 23, 2000}}{{subscription required}}{{cite news | url=http://money.cnn.com/2000/05/22/deals/vignette/ | title=Vignette buys OnDisplay | work=[[CNNMoney]] | date=May 22, 2000}}{{cite news | url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/vignette-buys-ondisplay-in-1-7b-deal/ | title=Vignette buys OnDisplay in $1.7B deal | work=[[ZDNet]] | date=May 22, 2000}} By June 2000, the company had 1,300 employees and its stock had risen more than 1,500% from its IPO price, to $297 per share, giving the company a [[market capitalization]] of nearly $9 billion. In August 2000, the company signed a deal with [[IBM]].{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB965260740724758369 | title=IBM Signs Joint Marketing Agreement In Deal With Software Vendor Vignette | first=William M. | last=Bulkeley | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=August 3, 2000}}{{subscription required}} In March 2001, Thomas E. Hogan was named president of the company.{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB983889616424076761 | title=Vignette Names Siebel's Hogan As President, Operating Chief | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=March 7, 2001}}{{subscription required}} In April 2001, as the dot-com bubble burst, the company sued 13 customers that had not paid for software they received.{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2001/04/16/story7.html | title=Vignette goes after debts | first=Shannon | last=Rentner | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=April 15, 2001}} In February 2002, the company's products were used for the website of [[The Wall Street Journal]].{{cite news | url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/2586934/networking/wsj-com-completes-web-site-overhaul.html | title=WSJ.com Completes Web Site Overhaul | first=Julia | last=King | work=[[Computerworld]] | date=February 11, 2002}} In July 2002, Hogan was named CEO.{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2002/07/22/daily4.html | title=Vignette names new CEO | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=July 22, 2002}} In October 2002, the company acquired Epicentric for $32 million.{{cite news | url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/2578506/enterprise-applications/vignette-to-acquire-epicentric-portal-developer.html | title=Vignette to acquire Epicentric portal developer | first=Jennifer | last=Mears | work=[[Computerworld]] | date=October 29, 2002}}{{cite news | url=http://www.eweek.com/it-management/vignette-to-acquire-epicentric | title=Vignette to Acquire Epicentric | first=Dennis | last=Callaghan | work=[[eWeek]] | date=October 29, 2002}} The company also announced Vignette V7.{{cite news | url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/2578908/app-development/vignette-unveils-new-content-management-products.html | title=Vignette unveils new content management products | first=Todd R. | last=Weiss | work=[[Computerworld]] | date=October 22, 2002}} In March 2003, the company moved its offices.{{cite news | url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/stories/2003/03/24/story7.html | title=Vignette moving offices | first=Matt | last=Hudgins | work=[[American City Business Journals]] | date=March 23, 2003}} In December 2003, the company acquired CMS vendor Intraspect for $20 million.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20031211005097/en/Vignette-Completes-Acquisition-Collaboration-Leader-Intraspect-Software | title=Vignette Completes Acquisition of Collaboration Leader Intraspect Software Inc. | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=December 11, 2003}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2003/09/25/vignette_buys_intraspect/ | title=Vignette buys Intraspect | work=[[The Register]] | date=September 25, 2003}} In March 2004, the company acquired Tower Technology, an [[Australia]]n-based provider of enterprise document and records management software, for $125 million.{{cite news | url=https://www.zdnet.com/article/vignette-buys-tower-technology/ | title=Vignette buys Tower Technology | first=James | last=Pearce | work=[[ZDNet]] | date=January 23, 2004}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/01/30/vignette_buys_into_traditional_ecm/ | title=Vignette buys into traditional ECM with Tower Technology | work=[[The Register]] | date=January 30, 2004}} In February 2006, the company appointed Mike Aviles as CEO.{{cite press release | url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20060214005421/en/Vignette-Appoints-Michael-A.-Aviles-Chief-Executive | title=Vignette Appoints Michael A. Aviles as Chief Executive Officer; Seasoned Executive Brings Leadership, Multi-Industry Experience and Operational Expertise | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | date=February 14, 2006}} In April 2008, the company acquired Vidavee, a [[SaaS]]-based Web video publishing company, for $6.6 million.{{cite news | url=http://adage.com/article/web-video-report-news/vignette-buys-vidavee-6-6-mil/129076/ | title=VIGNETTE BUYS VIDAVEE FOR $6.6 MIL | author=Sergio | work=[[Advertising Age]] | date=April 9, 2008}}{{cite news | url=https://www.computerworld.com.au/article/211975/vignette_acquires_video_publishing_capability_vidavee_buy/ | title=Vignette acquires video publishing capability with Vidavee buy | first=Sandra | last=Rossi | work=[[Computerworld]] | date=April 10, 2008}}{{cite news | url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/vignette-to-acquire-video-white-labeler-vidavee-for-66-million-sale-price-below-total-raise/ | title=Vignette To Acquire Video White Labeler Vidavee For $6.6 Million; Sale Price Below Total Raise | first=Joseph | last=Weisenthal | work=[[CBS News]] | date=April 9, 2008}} On July 21, 2009, [[Open Text Corporation]] acquired the company for $321 million in cash and stock.{{cite press release | url=https://www.opentext.com/who-we-are/press-releases?id=2233 | title=Open Text Completes Vignette Acquisition | publisher=[[Open Text Corporation]] | date=July 21, 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist|1}} [[Category:Companies established in 1996]] [[Category:Dot-com bubble]] [[Category:1999 initial public offerings]] [[Category:2009 mergers and acquisitions]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Wakestock | image = | caption= | location = [[Toronto Islands]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] | years_active = 2005 - | founders = | dates =}} The '''Wakestock Action Sports and Music Festival''' is a [[wakeboarding]] contest and Canada's largest action sports and [[music]] [[festival]]{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}}. It is held in [[Ontario, Canada]] on the [[Toronto Islands]], [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]]. The name Wakestock refers to the famous outdoor music festival [[Woodstock]].
==History== Wakestock was born out of Bala, Ontario.
In 2005, the festival was moved to Toronto Islands from August 11–14. Each year the [[wakeboard]] competition is accompanied by a music festival. There are several stages with different bands playing throughout day.
There are also other attractions—in 2005 there was a [[skatepark]] set up for anyone with a [[skateboard]]. There was a Pro Freestyle [[motocross]] demonstration as well as a rail competition set up for wakeboarders. There are also separate designated alcohol serving areas because the entire festival is for all ages.
Wakestock 2015 was canceled and 2016 never got beyond planning stages.
==Move to Collingwood== On August 9, 2009, Wakestock moved to Collingwood.
==2007: Wakestock 10== The Toronto wakeboarding festival celebrated ten years in 2007 with a {{Convert|400|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Oakley Pool (designed py Pat Panakos), as well as a music festival featuring the [[Deftones]], [[Goldfinger (band)|Goldfinger]], [[De La Soul]], [[Story of the Year]], and [[Lupe Fiasco]] on the [[Telus]] main stage.
The winners of Wakestock 10 were as follows:
Malibu Boats Pro Expression Session: Men *1st) Phillip Soven *2nd) Andrew Adikinson *3rd) Jeff Weatherall
Malibu Boats Pro Expression Session: Women *1st) Amber Wing *2nd) Sunni-Anne Ball *3rd) Barrett Pearlman
Billabong Pro Railslide *1st) Keith Lidberg *2nd) Aaron Rathy *3rd) Kevin Henshaw
Oakley Pool Jam: Best Trick *Shane Bonifay
== See also == * [[Wakestock (Wales)]]
